page.title: Association for the Social Scientific Study of Jewry

revision.comment: /* Purpose */
revision.text:
The '''Association for the Social Scientific Study of Jewry''' (ASSJ) is a [[Interdisciplinarity|cross-disciplinary]] organization of individuals whose research concerns the [[Jews|Jewish people]] throughout the world.
==Purpose== The ASSJ comprises primarily [[Academia|academics]], but also [[Policy analysis|policy analysts]], [[Community service|communal professionals]], and activists whose research concerns the Jewish people throughout the world. Social scientific disciplines represented include [[sociology]], [[social psychology]], [[social anthropology]], [[demography]], contemporary history, [[social work]], [[political science]], [[economics]], and [[Jewish education]]. Members work throughout the world but primarily in North America, [[Israel]], and Europe.<ref name = ASSJ1>{{cite web|title=Association for the Social Scientific Study of Jewry |url=http://www.contemporaryjewry.org/index.html|accessdate=24 December 2010}}</ref>
The ASSJ encourages and facilitates contact among researchers, supports the dissemination of research, and assists in the cultivation of younger scholars.<ref name = ASSJ1/>
==Past presidents== *[[Mervin F. Verbit]] (1971-1973)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://hirr.hartsem.edu/ency/ASSJ.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-12-21 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131011220501/http://hirr.hartsem.edu/ency/ASSJ.htm |archivedate=2013-10-11 }}</ref> *[[Marshall Sklare]] (1973-1975) *[[Samuel Klausner]] (1975-1977) *[[Celia Heller]] (1977-1979) *[[Chaim Waxman]] (1979-1981) *[[Harold Himmelfarb]] (1981-1983) *[[Egon Mayer (sociologist)|Egon Mayer]] (1983-1988) *[[Rela Mintz Geffen]] (1988-1990) *[[Arnold Dashefsky]] (1990-1996) *[[Allen Glicksman]] (1996-2000) * Sherry Israel (2000-2005) *[[Harriet Hartman]]<ref>http://www.contemporaryjewry.org/resources/Volume+1+Number+1+ASSJ+Newsletter.pdf</ref> (2005-2012) *[[Steven M. Cohen]]<ref>http://www.contemporaryjewry.org/9.html</ref> (2012-2016) *[[Leonard Saxe]] (2016-)
==Past vice presidents== * Harriet Hartman * Shaul Kelner (2005-2008) * [[Sylvia Barack Fishman]] (2008-2012) * [[Sergio DellaPergola]] (2012-2016) * Sarah Benor (2016-)
==Past treasurers== * Carmel Chiswick * Gail Glicksman * Bruce Phillips (2012-2015) * [[Leonard Saxe]] (2015-2016) * Matthew Boxer (2016-)
==Past secretaries== * Uzi Rebhun * Benjamin Phillips (2008-2010) * Theodore Sasson (2010-2012) * Matthew Boxer (2012-2016) * Jennifer Thompson (2016-)
==Publication== The organization publishes a journal, ''[[Contemporary Jewry]]'', several times a year with research articles that draw on a range of [[Social science|social scientific]] fields and methodologies.<ref name = ASSJ1/>
==The Marshall Sklare Award== The [[Marshall Sklare Award]] is an annual honor of the Association for the Social Scientific Study of Jewry (ASSJ). The ASSJ seeks to recognize "a senior scholar who has made a significant scholarly contribution to the social scientific study of Jewry." In most cases, the recipient has given a scholarly address. In recent years, the honored scholar has presented the address at the annual meeting of the [[Association for Jewish Studies]]. The award is named after sociologist [[Marshall Sklare]].
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.contemporaryjewry.org/index.html ASSJ website] *[http://www.bjpa.org/Publications/results.cfm?Publisher=Association%20for%20the%20Social%20Scientific%20Study%20of%20Jewry%20%28ASSJ%29 ASSJ full-text publications] on the Berman Jewish Policy Archive @ NYU Wagner *[http://www.bjpa.org/Publications/results.cfm?PublicationName=Contemporary%20Jewry ''Contemporary Jewry'' full text articles] on the Berman Jewish Policy Archive @ NYU Wagner
[[Category:Jewish society]] [[Category:Social sciences organizations]] [[Category:Ethnic studies organizations]]

revision.comment: [[Wikipedia:OABOT|Open access bot]]: add pmc identifier to citation with #oabot.
revision.text:
The '''Association of Religion Data Archives''' ('''ARDA''') is a free source of online information related to American and international [[religion]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thearda.com/about/ |title=The Association of Religion Data Archives | About the ARDA |website=Thearda.com |date= |accessdate=2017-01-06}}</ref> One of the primary goals of the archive is to democratize access to academic information on religion by making this information as widely accessible as possible.<ref name="Berkley Center">{{cite web|last=Berkley Center|first=Georgetown University|title=Association of Religion Data Archives|url=http://berkleycenter.georgetown.edu/resources/organizations/association-of-religion-data-archives|work=Resources on Faith, Ethics, and the Public Life|accessdate=18 October 2013}}</ref> Over 900 surveys, membership reports, and other data collections are currently available for online preview, and most can be downloaded free of charge. Other features include national profiles, [[GIS]] maps, church membership overviews, denominational heritage trees, historical timelines, tables, charts, and other summary reports.
Founded as the American Religion Data Archive in 1997, and online since 1998,<ref name="Berkley Center"/> the archive was initially targeted at researchers interested in American religion. In February 2006, the American Religion Data Archive became the Association of Religion Data Archives when an international data archive was added.<ref name="Finke 2007 21–34">{{cite journal|last=Finke|first=Roger |author2=Christopher D. Bader |author3=Edward C. Polson|title=A Growing Web of Resources: The Association of Religion Data Archives (ARDA)|journal=Review of Religion Research|year=2007|volume=49|issue=1|pages=21–34}}</ref> The archive now includes both American and international collections as well as features for educators, journalists, religious congregations, and researchers.
Data included in the ARDA are submitted by the foremost religion scholars and research centers in the world. Currently housed in the Social Science Research Institute at [[Pennsylvania State University]], the ARDA is funded by [[Lilly Endowment]], the [[John Templeton Foundation]], [[Chapman University]], and Pennsylvania State University.<ref name="Finke 2007 21–34"/>
==History== [[Roger Finke]], then professor of sociology at [[Purdue University]], founded the American Religion Data Archive in 1996 on a grant from [[Lilly Endowment]]. Data file collection and processing began in 1997. The online archive launched in the fall of 1998 under the domain name www.thearda.com, and originally contained thirty-three surveys regarding American religion.<ref name="Merino 2008- 2009 3–17"/> Within ten years, the archive had expanded to include more than 400 data files. {{As of|2016}}, more than 900 data files were available for download on the ARDA website.
Starting in 2005, the ARDA began to host surveys dealing with religion outside the United States.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Finke|first=Roger|author2=Amy Adamczyk|title=The Association of Religion Data Archives (ARDA): Online Research Data, Tools, and References|journal=Politics and Religion|year=2008|volume=1|issue=3|pages=456–470|doi=10.1017/s1755048308000412|pmid=25484914|pmc=4254728}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Finke|first=Roger|author2=Christopher D. Bader|author3=Edward C. Polson|title=A Growing Web of Resources: The Association of Religion Data Archives (ARDA) www.theARDA.com|journal=Review of Religious Research|year=2007|volume=49|issue=1|pages=21–34}}</ref> In 2006, the archive therefore changed its name from the American Religion Data Archive to the Association of Religion Data Archives to more properly reflect the scope of information available. The new name preserved both the acronym and the domain name from the American Religion Data Archive.<ref name="Merino 2008- 2009 3–17">{{cite journal|last=Merino|first=Stephen M|author2=Roger Finke|title=Stimulating Research and Discovery in the Study of Religion: The Association of Religion Data Archives (www.theARDA.com)|journal=Geographies of Religions and Belief Systems|year=2008–2009|volume=3|issue=1|pages=3–17}}</ref>
Since its founding, the ARDA has moved from Purdue to the Population Research Institute at [[Pennsylvania State University]],<ref name="Merino 2008- 2009 3–17"/> where is still run under the direction of Roger Finke, with the assistance of Christopher Bader of Chapman University.<ref name="ARDA">{{cite web|title=ARDA|url=http://www.thearda.com/about/|work=About the ARDA|accessdate=15 November 2013}}</ref> The staff has, since 1997, expanded to include a research team of religion experts and graduate students, a marketing and web development team, a team of editors for guiding papers and working papers, a learning center editor, and a press room editor.<ref name="ARDA"/>
==Overview== The primary component of the ARDA, the data archive, contains around 775 quantitative data files {{as of|2014|02|lc=y}}.<ref name="Data Archive Alphabetical Listing">{{cite web|title=Data Archive Alphabetical Listing|url=http://www.thearda.com/Archive/Browse_a.asp|work=ARDA|accessdate=17 February 2014}}</ref> ARDA staff do not themselves collect the data encompassed in these files; rather, the surveys' principal investigators submit their data to the ARDA for processing and archiving.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Merino|first=Stephen M.|author2=Roger Finke|title=Stimulating Research and Discovery in the Study of Religion: The Association of Religion Data Archives (www.theARDA.com)|journal=Geographies of Religions and Belief Systems|date=2008|volume=3|issue=1|pages=3–17}}</ref> Thus, the data files currently included in the archive originate from almost 200 different sources. Major data file contributors include the Presbyterian Panel Survey, the Southern Focus Poll, the U.S. Congregational Life Survey, and the Middletown Area Study. Data from the [[General Social Survey]], the [[American National Election Studies]], the World Religion Dataset, and the [[Pew Research Center]] are also available.<ref name="Data Archive Alphabetical Listing"/> Among the most common topics of information included are public opinions regarding social issues (e.g. [[abortion]], homosexuality, the role of women), survey respondents' perceptions of God/the divine, and survey respondents' religious affiliations.<ref>{{cite web|title=Measurement Wizard|url=http://www.thearda.com/MaWizard/|work=ARDA|accessdate=17 February 2014}}</ref>
In addition to archived survey data, the ARDA also provides information regarding the religious composition of, and the state of religious freedom in, the 232 nations currently recognized by the [[United States State Department]];<ref>{{cite web|title=National Profiles|url=http://www.thearda.com/internationalData/|work=ARDA|accessdate=17 February 2014}}</ref> membership and distributional data and historical lineages ("Family Trees") of major world religions and U.S. denominations thereof;<ref>{{cite web|title=Religious Group Profiles|url=http://www.thearda.com/denoms/families/groups.asp|work=ARDA|accessdate=17 February 2014}}</ref> and various learning tools.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Learning Center|url=http://www.thearda.com/learningcenter/|work=ARDA|accessdate=17 February 2014}}</ref>
A bi-weekly journalistic article dealing with matters of religion and (usually American) public life, written by David Briggs, also appears on the ARDA website.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Press Room|url=http://blogs.thearda.com/trend/|work=ARDA|accessdate=17 February 2014}}</ref> This article is cross-posted to the [[Huffington Post]], for which Briggs also writes.<ref>{{cite web|title=David Briggs|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/david-briggs/|work=The Huffington Post|accessdate=17 February 2014}}</ref>
In 2015, the ARDA began providing interactive historical timelines of religion in the United States.<ref>{{cite web|title=American Religion Timelines|url=http://thearda.com/timeline/|website=Association of Religion Data Archives|accessdate=27 October 2016}}</ref> Currently, there are three interactive timelines listed: Prominent Religious Events and People, Baptist Events and People, and Catholic Events and People.
==Affiliations== The ARDA is both affiliated with and funded by the following organizations:<ref name="Finke 2007 21–34"/><ref name="thearda.com">{{cite web|title=ARDA|url=http://www.thearda.com/|accessdate=27 November 2013}}</ref>
* [[Lilly Endowment]] * The [[John Templeton Foundation]] * [[Pennsylvania State University]] * [[Chapman University]]
The ARDA is affiliated with the following organizations without funding:<ref name="thearda.com"/>
* The Association for the Study of Religion, Economics, and Culture * The [[Bar Ilan University]] Religion and State Project * The International Association of Religion Journalists * The Portrait of American Life Survey
==Awards and recognition== * The ARDA was one of thirty online resources selected by the [[Reference and User Services Association]] (RUSA) division of the [[American Library Association]] for the 2010 Best Free Reference Websites List.<ref>{{cite web|title=Best Free Reference Websites 2010 Twelfth Annual List RUSA Machine-Assisted Reference Section (MARS)|url=http://www.ala.org/rusa/sections/mars/marspubs/marsbestfreewebsites/marsbestfree2010|work=Reference and User Services Association|accessdate=24 October 2013}}</ref> * The Lilly Endowment's "Insights into Religion" portal lists the ARDA as one of the best online resources for continuing education about religion,<ref>{{cite web|title=Best Resources for Continuing Education|url=http://religioninsights.org/best-resources-continuing-education|work=Insights into Religion|accessdate=14 November 2013}}</ref> demographic research, youth research,<ref>{{cite web|title=Insights into Religion|url=http://religioninsights.org/best-resources-demographic-research|work=Best Resources for Demographic Research: Current and Historic Demographic Information for Your Parish|accessdate=14 November 2013}}</ref> and teaching religion.<ref>{{cite web|title=Best Resources for Youth Research|url=http://religioninsights.org/best-resources-youth-research|work=Insights into Religion|accessdate=14 November 2013}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Religion and the internet]] * [[Adherents.com]]
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==External links== *[http://www.TheARDA.com Association of Religion Data Archives]
[[Category:Archives]] [[Category:Religious websites]]

revision.text:
[[Image:Axel Boëthius.JPG|thumb|right|150px|Axel Boëthius]] '''Axel [[Boëthius (family)|Boëthius]]''' (July 18, 1889 in [[Arvika]], [[Sweden]] – May 7, 1969 in [[Rome]], [[Italy]]) was a scholar and archaeologist of [[Etruscan civilization|Etruscan]] culture. Boëthius was primarily a student of Etruscan and Italic architecture. His father was the historian [[Simon Boëthius]].<ref>Medwid, Linda M. ''The Makers of Classical Archaeology: A Reference Work''. New York: Humanity Books, 2000 pp. 42–43.</ref><ref>Williams, Shellie. "Boëthius, Axel." ''Encyclopedia of the History of Classical Archaeology''. Nancy Thomson de Grummond, ed. Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 1996, vol. 1, pp. 167–8.</ref>
As a student, Boëthius studied at the [[Uppsala University]], where he completed his Ph.D. in 1918. He taught at Uppsala (1921–24) during which time he excavated at [[Mycenae]] in Greece. In 1925 he was selected as the first director of the [[Swedish Institute at Rome]] by the Swedish crown prince [[Gustaf VI Adolf of Sweden|Gustav Adolf]] (also known as an accomplished amateur archaeologist). He became professor of archaeology at the [[Göteborg University]] in 1934, a post he held until 1955. He also served as rector of the university (1946–51). In 1955, he retired to Italy. There he published his book ''Golden House of Nero'' in 1960, which was the product of the Thomas Spencer Jerome Lectures<ref>https://www.press.umich.edu/browse/series/UM18</ref> given in Rome.<ref name="Boethius2013">{{cite book|author=Axel Boethius|title=The Golden House of Nero: Some Aspects of Roman Architecture|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Hu38mwEACAAJ|date=20 April 2013|publisher=Literary Licensing, LLC|isbn=978-1-258-67096-2}}</ref> Boëthius, working together with [[John Bryan Ward-Perkins]], wrote the section on Etruscan architecture for the prestigious ''Pelican History of Art'' series. The volume was published in 1970, shortly after his death in 1969.<ref name="BoëthiusLing1978">{{cite book|author1=Axel Boëthius|author2=Roger Ling|author3=Tom Rasmussen|title=Etruscan and Early Roman Architecture|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=1nZswjfqROUC|year=1978|publisher=Yale University Press|isbn=978-0-300-05290-9}}</ref><ref>Ward-Perkins, John. [addendum to Forward]. ''Etruscan and Roman Architecture''. Pelican History of Art 32. Baltimore: Penguin, 1970, p. [xxv].</ref>
==Publications== * [dissertation:] ''Die Pythaïs: Studien zur Geschichte der Verbindungen zwischen Athen und Delphi''. Uppsala: Almquist & Wiksells, 1918. * and Ward-Perkins, John. ''Etruscan and Roman Architecture''. Pelican History of Art 32. Baltimore: Penguin, 1970. Revised edition as: Axel Boëthius, Roger Ling, Tom Rasmussen, ''Etruscan and Early Roman Architecture'', Yale University Press Pelican history of art, 1978, Yale University Press, {{ISBN|0300052901}}, 9780300052909 * ''The Golden House of Nero: some Aspects of Roman Architecture''. Ann Arbor, MI: University of Michigan Press,1960. * and Sahlen, Nils G. ''Etruscan Culture, Land and People: Archaeological Research and Studies Conducted in [[San Giovenale]] and its Environs by Members of the Swedish Institute in Rome''. New York: Columbia University Press, 1963.
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
{{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Boethius, Axel}} [[Category:Swedish archaeologists]] [[Category:Classical archaeologists]] [[Category:Swedish classical scholars]] [[Category:Etruscan scholars]] [[Category:University of Gothenburg faculty]] [[Category:1889 births]] [[Category:1969 deaths]] [[Category:Fellows of the British Academy]] [[Category:Burials at Uppsala old cemetery]]

revision.comment: add template 'Lucian Freud'
revision.text:
[[File:Benefits Supervisor Sleeping.jpg|thumb|440px|''Benefits Supervisor Sleeping'', Lucian Freud, 1995.]] '''''Benefits Supervisor Sleeping''''' is a 1995 oil on canvas [[painting]] by [[Lucian Freud]] depicting an obese, naked woman lying on a couch. It is a [[portrait]] of [[Sue Tilley]], a Job Centre supervisor{{Cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/art/11608941/I-didnt-set-out-to-be-Lucian-Freuds-muse.html|title=I didn't set out to be Lucian Freud's muse|last=Tilley|first=Sue|date=May 16, 2015|website=The Telegraph|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=May 21, 2018}}, then weighing about {{convert|127|kg|lb}}.{{cite news | url = http://www.centurion-magazine.com/home/art-and-culture/culture/portraits-of-an-artist.html | title = Portraits of an Artist | accessdate = 2014-03-12 | publisher = [[Centurion Magazine]] | date = 2012-01-12 | last = Hosea | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20140318031211/http://www.centurion-magazine.com/home/art-and-culture/culture/portraits-of-an-artist.html | archivedate = 2014-03-18 | df = }} Tilley is the author of a biography of the Australian performer [[Leigh Bowery]] titled ''Leigh Bowery, The Life and Times of an Icon''. Tilley was introduced to Freud by Bowery, who was already modelling for him. Freud painted a number of large portraits of her around the period 1994–96, and came to call her "Big Sue". He said of her body "It's flesh without muscle and it has developed a different kind of texture through bearing such a weight-bearing thing".[[National Portrait Gallery, London|National Portrait Gallery]], Exhibition booklet for ''Lucian Freud Portraits'', 2012, Section VII The painting held the world record for the highest price paid for a painting by a living artist when it was sold by [[Guy Naggar]]http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/cbdd4f36-5529-11dd-ae9c-000077b07658.html#axzz3l3nusfDK for US$33.6 million (£17.2 million){{cite news | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/7398949.stm | title = Freud work sets new world record | accessdate = 2008-05-14 | publisher = [[BBC Online]] | date=2008-05-14}} at [[Christie's]] in New York in May 2008 to [[Roman Abramovich]].{{cite news | url = https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/1981367/Roman-Abramovich-revealed-as-Freud-and-Bacon-buyer.html | title = Roman Abramovich 'revealed as Freud and Bacon buyer' | accessdate = 2008-05-18 | publisher = ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' | location = London | first = Stephen | last = Adams | date = 2008-05-18 }} Freud's painting ''Benefits Supervisor Resting'', sold for £35.8million ($56.2million) in 2015 after his death in 2011, replacing ''Benefits Supervisor Sleeping'' as the most expensive Freud painting sold at auction.{{Cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-3082464/1994-Freud-titled-Benefits-Supervisor-Resting-sells-auction-35-8million.html|title=Benefits Supervisor Resting by Freud auctioned for £35.8million|work=Mail Online|access-date=2018-05-22}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.hull2017.co.uk/discover/article/lipstick-leigh-bowery-lucian-freuds-35m-muse/|title=Lipstick, Leigh Bowery and me… by Lucian Freud’s £35m muse – Hull UK City of Culture 2017|work=Hull UK City of Culture 2017|access-date=2017-07-25|language=en-US}}
The painting was exhibited twice at Flowers Gallery:
*1996: ''Naked'' – Flowers East at London Fields *1997: ''British Figurative Art - Part 1: Painting'' at Flowers East == References == {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.christies.com/LotFinder/lot_details.aspx?intObjectID=5074074 Lot Details on Christies.com] {{Italic title}} {{Lucian Freud}} [[Category:Paintings by Lucian Freud]] [[Category:Nude art]] [[Category:1995 paintings]] [[Category:Portraits of women]] {{art-stub}}

revision.comment: Alter: isbn, title. Removed parameters. You can [[WP:UCB|use this bot]] yourself. [[WP:DBUG|Report bugs here]]. | [[WP:UCB|User-activated]].
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2012}} '''Betteridge's law of headlines''' is an [[adage]] that states: "Any headline that ends in a question mark can be answered by the word ''no''." It is named after Ian Betteridge, a British technology journalist who wrote about it in 2009,<ref name="betteridge2009">{{cite web |author=Betteridge, Ian |url=http://www.technovia.co.uk/2009/02/techcrunch-irresponsible-journalism.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090226202006/http://www.technovia.co.uk/2009/02/techcrunch-irresponsible-journalism.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=26 February 2009 |title=TechCrunch: Irresponsible journalism |publisher=Technovia.co.uk |date=23 February 2009 |accessdate=27 June 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Macalope |first=The |url=http://www.macworld.com/article/1168107/macalope_pointless_exercises.html |title=The Macalope Weekly: Pointless Exercises |publisher=Macworld |date=2012-08-11 |accessdate=2012-11-08}}</ref> although the principle is much older. As with similar "laws" (e.g., [[Murphy's law]]), it is intended to be humorous rather than the literal truth.<ref>Gooden, Philip (2010). Skyscrapers, Hemlines and the Eddie Murphy Rule (1st ed.), Ch. 3</ref>
The maxim has been cited by other names since as early as 1991, when a published compilation of Murphy's Law variants called it "'''Davis's law'''",<ref>Bloch, Arthur. The Complete Murphy's Law: A Definitive Collection. Rev. ed. Los Angeles, Calif.: Price Stern Sloan, 1991. Accessed September 25, 2016. https://books.google.com/books?id=tph7EdvSa0EC.</ref> a name that also crops up online, without any explanation of who Davis was.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.houseofgoldbergs.com/Docs/Humor/murphyAll.txt |title=List of variants of Murphy's Law |date= |accessdate=2012-11-08}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Liberman |first=Mark |url=http://itre.cis.upenn.edu/~myl/languagelog/archives/003585.html |title=Language Log: Davis Law |publisher=Itre.cis.upenn.edu |date=2006-09-17 |accessdate=2012-11-08}}</ref> It has also been called just the "'''journalistic principle'''",<ref>{{cite web|url=http://murphyslaws.net/edition.htm |title=Murphy's Laws: Journalistic Principle |publisher=Murphyslaws.net |date=1997 |accessdate=2012-11-08}}</ref> and in 2007 was referred to in commentary as "an old truism among journalists".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://meatrobot.org.uk/post/20793051/its-an-old-truism-among-journalists-that-if-a |title="It's an old truism among journalists ..." 2007 |publisher=Meatrobot.org.uk |date=2007-12-04 |accessdate=2012-11-08}}. The reference is to a post in the comment section of the blog [http://www.dcscience.net/2007/11/21/dont-trust-boots/ DC's Improbable Science], dated Nov 22, 2007.</ref>
== History ==
Ian Betteridge's name became associated with the concept after he discussed it in a February 2009 article, which examined a previous [[TechCrunch]] article that carried the headline "Did [[Last.fm]] Just Hand Over User Listening Data to the [[RIAA]]?":<ref>[https://techcrunch.com/2009/02/20/did-lastfm-just-hand-over-user-listening-data-to-the-riaa/ "Did Last.fm Just Hand Over User Listening Data To the RIAA?"]</ref>
{{quote|This story is a great demonstration of my maxim that any headline which ends in a question mark can be answered by the word "no." The reason why journalists use that style of headline is that they know the story is probably bullshit, and don’t actually have the sources and facts to back it up, but still want to run it.<ref name="betteridge2009" />}}
A similar observation was made by British newspaper editor [[Andrew Marr]] in his 2004 book ''My Trade'', among Marr's suggestions for how a reader should interpret newspaper articles:
{{quote|If the headline asks a question, try answering 'no'. Is This the True Face of Britain's Young? (Sensible reader: No.) Have We Found the Cure for AIDS? (No; or you wouldn't have put the question mark in.) Does This Map Provide the Key for Peace? (Probably not.) A headline with a question mark at the end means, in the vast majority of cases, that the story is tendentious or over-sold. It is often a scare story, or an attempt to elevate some run-of-the-mill piece of reporting into a national controversy and, preferably, a national panic. To a busy journalist hunting for real information a question mark means 'don't bother reading this bit'.<ref name="My Trade">{{cite book |last=Marr |first=Andrew |title=My Trade: a short history of British journalism |year=2004 |publisher=Macmillan |location=London |isbn=978-1-4050-0536-4 |page=253}}</ref>}}
== Outside journalism == In the field of [[particle physics]], the concept is known as '''Hinchliffe's Rule''',<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/cosmicvariance/2006/12/07/guest-blogger-joe-polchinski-on-the-string-debates|title = Guest Blogger: Joe Polchinski on the String Debates|date = 7 December 2006|accessdate = 16 May 2014|website = Cosmic Variance|publisher = Discover Magazine|last = |first = }}</ref><ref name="peon"/> after physicist [[Ian Hinchliffe]],<ref name="improb">{{cite journal|url=https://www.improbable.com/airchives/paperair/volume21/v21i3/Consistent-with-Hinchliffe-21-3.pdf |first=Stuart M. |last=Shieber |title=Is This Article Consistent with Hinchliffe's Rule? |journal=Annals of Improbable Research |date=May–June 2015 |volume=21 |number=3}}</ref> who stated that if a research paper's title is in the form of a yes–no question, the answer to that question will be "no".<ref name="improb"/> The adage led into a humorous attempt at a [[Liar paradox|liar's paradox]] by a pseudonymous 1988 paper which bore the title "Is Hinchliffe’s Rule True?"<ref name="peon">{{Cite web|last=Peon|first=Boris|url = http://ccdb5fs.kek.jp/cgi-bin/img/allpdf?199007095|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20160410022155/http://ccdb5fs.kek.jp/cgi-bin/img/allpdf?199007095|dead-url = yes|archive-date = 10 April 2016|title = Is Hinchliffe's Rule True?|date = 4 August 1988|accessdate = 21 November 2016}}</ref><ref name="improb"/>
However, at least one article found that the "law" does not apply in research literature.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Cook|first=James M.|last2=Plourde|first2=Dawn|date=2016-06-25|title=Do scholars follow Betteridge's Law? The use of questions in journal article titles|journal=Scientometrics|language=en|volume=108|issue=3|pages=1119–1128|doi=10.1007/s11192-016-2030-2|issn=0138-9130}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Clickbait]] *[[List of eponymous laws]] *[[Loaded question]] *[[Sensationalism]]
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==External links== {{Wiktionary|Betteridge's law}}
*[http://betteridgeslaw.com betteridgeslaw.com], a website that lists articles where Betteridge's law applies. *[https://web.archive.org/web/20100710042734/http://www.technovia.co.uk/ Ian Betteridge's website] *[https://www.reddit.com/r/QTWTAIN Reddit's QTWTAIN (Question To Which The Answer Is No) page]
[[Category:2009 introductions]] [[Category:Adages]] [[Category:Criticism of journalism]] [[Category:Paremiology]] [[Category:Skepticism]]

revision.text:
'''Cacography''' is deliberate comic [[misspelling]], a type of [[humour]] similar to [[malapropism]].<ref>"On the Real Side: Laughing, Lying, and Signifying: the Underground Tradition of African-American Humor that Transformed American Culture, from [[Slavery]] to [[Richard Pryor]]", by [[Mel Watkins]], 1994, {{ISBN|0-671-68982-7}}, [https://books.google.com/books?id=BrNZAAAAMAAJ&q=cacography&dq=cacography&lr=&pgis=1 pp. 60, 62]</ref><ref name=pattee>"A History of American Literature Since 1870" by Fred Lewis Pattee, 1917, [https://books.google.com/books?id=gs5ZAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA34&dq=%22deliberate+misspelling%22 p.34], digitized by Google Books</ref>
The term in the sense of "poor [[spelling]], [[diacritic|accentuation]], and [[punctuation]]" is a semantic [[antonym]] to [[orthography]],<ref>"A Practical Grammar of French Rhetoric, by Gabriel Surenne", 1846, [https://books.google.com/books?id=pTQEAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA150&dq=cacography#PPA150,M1p. 150], digitized by [[Google Books]]</ref> and in the sense of "poor [[handwriting]]" it is an etymological antonym to the word [[calligraphy]]: cacography is from [[Greek language|Greek]] κακός (''kakos'' "bad") and γραφή (''graphe'' "writing").
A common usage of cacography is to [[caricature]] illiterate speakers.<ref>"The literary content of the New York Spirit of the times, 1831-1856", by [[Richard Boyd Hauck]]", 1965, [https://books.google.com/books?id=uws_AAAAIAAJ&q=cacography&dq=cacography&lr=&pgis=1 p. 184]</ref>
==See also== {{Too many see alsos|date=December 2016}} *[[Sensational spelling]] *[[Catachresis]] *[[Gaffe]] *[[Typographical error]] *[[Corruption (linguistics)]] *[[Eye dialect]] *[[Teh]] *[[Pwn]] *[[Leet]]speak *[[Lolcat]] *[[Miguxês#Tiopês|Tiopês]]
== References == {{reflist}}
[[Category:Lexicology]] [[Category:Humour]] [[Category:Literary techniques]] [[Category:Nonstandard spelling]]
{{ling-stub}}

page.title: Center for Latin American Studies – University of Pittsburgh

revision.comment: Rescuing 5 sources and tagging 1 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta10)
revision.text:
{{Infobox university |image_name =CLAS Pitt logo.jpg |name = University of Pittsburgh
Center for Latin American Studies |established = 1964 |director = [[Scott Morgenster|Scott Morgenstern]] |city = [[Pittsburgh]] | state = [[Pennsylvania]] |country = United States | campus = Oakland (Main) |website = http://www.ucis.pitt.edu/clas/ }} The [[University of Pittsburgh]]’s '''Center for Latin American Studies''', commonly known as '''CLAS''', is a [[National Resource Center]] on Latin America.{{cite web | url=http://www.nrcweb.org/viewNRC.aspx?nNRCID=97 | title=Center for Latin American Studies | publisher=National Resource Centers | accessdate=2011-10-29 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120425124139/http://www.nrcweb.org/viewNRC.aspx?nNRCID=97# | archive-date=2012-04-25 | dead-url=yes | df= }} The Center, founded in 1964 as part of the university's [[University of Pittsburgh Center for International Studies|Center for International Studies]],{{cite news | url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=I7RRAAAAIBAJ&pg=2551%2C6716502 | title=Pitt's Latin connection | newspaper=Pittsburgh Post-Gazette | location=Pittsburgh, PA | date=1985-03-26 | accessdate=2011-10-29}} offers undergraduate and graduate students multidisciplinary training on [[Latin American studies|Latin American and Caribbean studies]]. ==Mission== The Center for Latin American Studies states that its mission is to "expand and enrich academic resources relating to Latin America and the Caribbean at the University of Pittsburgh".{{cite web | url=http://www.ucis.pitt.edu/clas/about.html | title=Center for Latin American Studies: About Us | publisher=University of Pittsburgh Center for International Studies | date=2011-09-06 | accessdate=2011-10-29 | archive-url=http://arquivo.pt/wayback/20090710015652/http://www.ucis.pitt.edu/clas/about.html# | archive-date=2009-07-10 | dead-url=yes | df= }} It assists students in gaining expertise in Latin American and Caribbean affairs, and encourages the faculty to "pursue research, enhance their expertise, and disseminate new knowledge on the region". CLAS shares its resources with academic local, national, and international academic communities, public and private sector organizations, as well as the general public. ==Location== [[File:University of Pittsburgh (looking South-West) seen from the Cathedral of Learning With Numbered Callouts May 14, 2010.jpg|thumb|The [[Oakland (Pittsburgh)|Oakland]] neighborhood of Pittsburgh]] CLAS is located on the University of Pittsburgh's main campus in the city’s [[Oakland (Pittsburgh)|Oakland]] neighborhood. CLAS’s offices are found in the Center for International Studies on the 4th floor of [[Wesley W. Posvar Hall|Welsey Posvar Hall]], Pitt’s largest academic building. Posvar Hall stands along Schenley Drive between Forbes Avenue and Roberto Clemente Drive. The Center is located on the former site of [[Forbes Field]] where the [[Pittsburgh Pirates]] played from 1909 to 1970 and won multiple [[World Series]].{{cite web | url=http://www.tour.pitt.edu/tour-040.html | title=Virtual Tour: Wesley Posvar Hall | publisher=University of Pittsburgh | accessdate=2011-10-29 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111003101638/http://www.tour.pitt.edu/tour-040.html | archivedate=2011-10-03 | df= }} ==History== [[File:Posvar Hall (WWPH) - evening Fall 2007.jpg|thumb|right|[[Posvar Hall]] is the primary location of CLAS]] The Center was formally founded on September 16, 1964 during Chancellor [[Edward H. Litchfield]]’s tenure at the University."The Story of a Center: 1964–2004, Latin America Invades Pittsburgh" by Cole Blaiser (Director of CLAS 1964–1974), part of the CLAS Latin American Monograph & Document Series Realizing the globalizing effect of World War II and witnessing the city of Pittsburgh’s role in global affairs, the Pitt administration became dedicated to transitioning from a University serving primarily Pennsylvania to one with a more global impact. Litchfield’s goal for the Center was to strengthen the University’s “International Dimension,” particularly with regard to Latin America. Litchfield cited Latin America’s “important economic, social and political ties with the United States” in advocating for the establishment of a Center.{{cite journal | url=http://digital.library.pitt.edu/cgi-bin/t/text/pageviewer-idx?xc=1;g=documentingpitt;xg=1;type=simple;didno=31735062134469;idno=31735062134469;view=image;seq=0005 | title=The Wide World of Pitt | first=Esther | last=Kitzes | journal=Pitt | page=3 | volume=19 | number=4 | publisher=University of Pittsburgh | location=Pittsburgh, PA | date=Fall 1964 | accessdate=2012-03-12}} With a five-year, $1.5 million grant from the [[Ford Foundation]] awarded in 1964, Litchfield hired political scientist Cole Blasier to direct the founding of the Center.{{cite news | url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=R2EqAAAAIBAJ&pg=5318%2C5509265 | title=Pitt Rising As Latin Study Center | first=Kenneth | last=Eskey | newspaper=The Pittsburgh Press | date=1967-10-29 | accessdate=2011-10-29}} Blasier worked in conjunction with the University’s history, political science and sociology departments to form CLAS. The original coalition of these three distinct departments provided the lasting example of interdisciplinary cooperation that defines the Center today. Each semester, over 120 Pitt professors in over 20 different departments teach more than 250 courses on Latin America and the Caribbean. Economist Carmelo Mesa-Lago became the Center's second director in 1977,{{cite news | url=http://www.post-gazette.com/magazine/19991003latinos1.asp | title=Pittsburgh's 'invisible' Latinos are emerging as part of a national population explosion | first=Diana Nelson | last=Jones | newspaper=Pittsburgh Post-Gazette | location=Pittsburgh, PA | date=1999-10-03 | accessdate=2011-10-29}} and while under his direction CLAS was officially designated a [[National Resource Center|National Resource Center in Latin American Studies]] in 1979. The designation provided further funding and national recognition for CLAS.Center for Latin American Studies (CLAS) Website – http://www.ucis.pitt.edu/clas/publications CLAS has been continuously funded by the US Department of Education as a National Resource Center since 1979. Following Mesa-Lago,other directors were Mitchell Seligson, William Dewalt, Kathleen Musante, Scott Morgenstern. ==Eduardo Lozano Latin American Library Collection== [[File:Eduardo lozano.jpg|thumb|Eduardo Lozano, founder and director of the Latin American Library Collection]] [[File:LatinroomHillman.jpg|thumb|The Collection's Latin American Reading Room in [[Hillman Library]]]] The collection was created and primarily built by Eduardo Lozano, a librarian, artist, poet, and author from [[Argentina]] who directed the Latin American Library from its creation until his death in 2006.{{cite news | url=http://www.post-gazette.com/pg/06239/716726-122.stm | title=Obituary: Eduardo F. Lozano / Noted Latin America bibliographer for Pitt's Hillman Library | first=Eleanor | last=Chute | newspaper=Pittsburgh Post-Gazette | location=Pittsburgh, PA | date=2006-08-27 | accessdate=2011-10-29}} Needing an organized resource center for CLAS, and with the help of [[Henry Hillman]]’s donation to the University for the new [[Hillman Library]], Cole Blasier hired Lozano to establish a Latin American library collection in 1967.{{cite journal | url=http://www.library.pitt.edu/uls/libreview/libreview/may97/volumes.html | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070114085936/http://www.library.pitt.edu/uls/libreview/libreview/may97/volumes.html | title=30 Years and 300,000-Plus Volumes | first=Lisa | last=Phillips | journal=Library Review | publisher=University Library System, University of Pittsburgh | location=Pittsburgh, PA | date=Spring 1997 | archivedate=2007-01-14 | accessdate=2011-10-29}} Lozano traveled annually throughout Latin America to buy books directly from the source. The collection was officially named the "Eduardo Lozano Latin American Library Collection" by the university in 1997{{cite news | url=http://www.utimes.pitt.edu/?p=5384 | title=Eduardo Lozano Book collector extraordinaire | first=Bruce | last=Steele | newspaper=University Times | publisher=University of Pittsburgh | location=Pittsburgh, PA | date=1997-05-29 | accessdate=2011-10-29}} and today is the eighth largest collection of Latin American resource materials in the United States{{cite news | url= http://www.post-gazette.com/localnews/20020926latin7.asp | first=Monica L. | last=Haynes | title= Pitt dedicates Latin American Reading Room at library | newspaper=Pittsburgh Post-Gazette | location=Pittsburgh, PA | date=2002-09-26 | accessdate=2011-10-29}} and includes over 500,000 volumes, 12,000 periodical titles, 110,000 reels of mircrofilms, 540 films and video recordings, and 630 sound recordings. More than 85% of the volumes are in [[Spanish language|Spanish]] or [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]] and the collection’s resources on [[Bolivia]] and [[Cuba]] are considered some of the world’s best. Over 400 libraries, research centers, universities, and governmental departments based in various locations around the world maintain exchange agreements with the collection.{{cite web|url=http://www.library.pitt.edu/libraries/latam/latam.html |title=Eduardo Lozano Latin American Collection |publisher=University Library System, University of Pittsburgh |accessdate=2011-10-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111112065033/http://www.library.pitt.edu/libraries/latam/latam.html |archivedate=2011-11-12 |df= }} In 2002, a Latin American inspired reading room, housing a portion of the Lozano Collection, was dedicated in the university's [[Hillman Library]].{{cite press release | url=http://digital.library.pitt.edu/cgi-bin/t/text/pageviewer-idx?cc=pittpressreleases;idno=pittpressreleases20020147;view=image;seq=0001 | title=New Latin American Reading Room to be Dedicated Sept. 25 in Pitt's Hillman Library | publisher=University of Pittsburgh | date=2002-09-23 | accessdate=2012-03-12}} Composed of arches and columns with windows on three sides, the room was designed by [[Peruvian]]-American architect Victor Beltran to be reminiscent of a Spanish courtyard. ==Undergraduate and graduate programs== Since 1968, CLAS has offered undergraduate students a program in Latin American studies. Students work towards receiving a certificate in Latin American studies in conjunction with their bachelor's degree. Graduates of the program therefore obtain interdisciplinary knowledge and field study in the Latin American region.{{cite web | url=http://www.ucis.pitt.edu/clas/students/study.html | title=CLAS: Programs of Study | publisher=University of Pittsburgh Center for International Studies | date=2011-08-31 | accessdate=2011-10-29 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20041027114329/http://www.ucis.pitt.edu/clas/students/study.html# | archive-date=2004-10-27 | dead-url=yes | df= }} These graduates have become administrators in the [[United Nations]], state and federal government officials, [[Peace Corps]] and Catholic relief service volunteers, foreign service officers in Argentina, [[Brazil]], and other countries, Spanish teachers, and many other professionals in a variety of fields.{{citation needed|date=October 2011}} The graduate program at CLAS is aimed at doctoral or master's students who want to incorporate a specialization in Latin America into their studies. Candidates for the graduate certificate must be proficient in Spanish, Portuguese, or an Amerindian language. Currently, four semesters of [[Quechua languages|Quechua]] are offered to fulfill the Amerindian language requirement. Two courses in the student’s major department and four courses in at least two departments outside are required for completion of the program, as is an interdisciplinary research paper in the field of Latin American studies. ==CLAS educational and public service outreach== As a National Resource Center on Latin America, the Outreach Program at CLAS plays a leading role in sharing information and resources on Latin American studies to educators of all academic levels and disciplines. CLAS' Outreach Program offers educational expertise from college level educators to [[kindergarten]] through [[Secondary education in the United States|secondary]] classes. In addition, CLAS seeks to provide resources to the professional community and the general public as part of its educational public service outreach mission. Outreach programs are offered throughout the academic year and include professional development workshops, study abroad opportunities, faculty development seminars, summer research fellowships, curriculum development projects, school visit programs, a resource lending library, and lecture and film series.{{cite web | url=http://www.ucis.pitt.edu/clas/outreach.html | title=Educational Public Service (Outreach) | publisher=University of Pittsburgh Center for International Studies | date=2011-08-31 | accessdate=2011-10-29 | archive-url=http://arquivo.pt/wayback/20090710015810/http://www.ucis.pitt.edu/clas/outreach.html# | archive-date=2009-07-10 | dead-url=yes | df= }} The center also published two in-house newsletters, ''CLASicos'' and ''Las Noticias'', and in concert with the [[University of Pittsburgh Press]], its faculty and staff are often involved in helping to produce scholarly publications and journals covering a range of Latin American topics.{{cite web | url=http://www.ucis.pitt.edu/clas/publications.html | title=Publications on the Latin American and Caribbean Region at the University of Pittsburgh | publisher=University of Pittsburgh Center for International Studies | date=2011-10-07 | accessdate=2011-10-29 | archive-url=http://arquivo.pt/wayback/20090710015030/http://www.ucis.pitt.edu/clas/publications.html# | archive-date=2009-07-10 | dead-url=yes | df= }} In addition, the center also hosts the website ''Panoramas'' which provides an on-line venue for a dialogue and academic discussion of Latin American and Caribbean issues.{{cite web|url=http://www.panoramas.pitt.edu/about|title=Panoramas: About|publisher=Center for Latin American Studies at the University of Pittsburgh|accessdate=June 3, 2013}} Since 1980,{{cite news | url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=N08NAAAAIBAJ&pg=3370%2C141670 | title=Nadie es Profeta... | newspaper=Pittsburgh Post-Gazette | location=Pittsburgh, PA | date=1980-02-02 | accessdate=2011-10-28}} CLAS has also hosted an annual Latin American and Caribbean Festival.{{cite news | url=http://www.pittsburghlive.com/x/pittsburghtrib/s_158419.html | title=Fest highlights Hispanic flavor | first=Erik | last=Siemers | newspaper=Pittsburgh Tribune-Review | date=2003-10-05 | accessdate=2011-10-29 }}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}{{cite news | url=http://www.pointparkglobe.com/features/festival-unites-latin-american-caribbean-communities-with-art-1.2120655#.TquuuGAzDC8 | title=Festival unites Latin American, Caribbean communities with art | first=Emily | last=Petsko | newspaper=The Globe | location=Pittsburgh, PA | date=2011-03-23 | accessdate=2011-10-29}} == References == {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.ucis.pitt.edu/clas/ CLAS Website] *''[http://www.panoramas.pitt.edu/ Panoramas]'' *[https://web.archive.org/web/20111112065033/http://www.library.pitt.edu/libraries/latam/latam.html University of Pittsburgh Library System] {{University of Pittsburgh}} {{coord|40.444167| -79.953056|display=title}} {{DEFAULTSORT:University of Pittsburgh Center For Latin American Studies}} [[Category:University of Pittsburgh]] [[Category:Latin American studies]]

{{More citations needed|date=February 2013}} {{infobox person |birth_place=[[Calcutta]], India |birth_date=October 31, 1870 |death_place=[[Victoria, British Columbia]], Canada |death_date={{dda|1945|3|8|1870|10|31}} |occupation=diplomat, writer, Tibetologist |image=Sir Charles Alfred Bell (Mw63447).jpg |caption=Bell in 1922 }} '''Sir Charles Alfred Bell''', [[Order of the Indian Empire|KCIE]] [[Order of St Michael and St George|CMG]] (October 31, 1870 – March 8, 1945) was the British Political Officer for [[Bhutan]], [[Sikkim]] and [[Tibet]]. He was known as "British India's ambassador to Tibet" before retiring and becoming a noted [[tibetologist]].
== Biography == He was educated at Winchester School and then at New College, Oxford, after which he joined the [[Indian Civil Service]] in 1891.<ref>{{cite book| editor1-first=Paul | editor1-last=Dimeo| editor2-first=James | editor2-last=Mills| title =Soccer in South Asia: Empire, Nation, Diaspora| chapter= 'Kicking the Buddha's Head': India, Tibet and Footballing Colonialism| chapterurl=https://books.google.com/books?id=O2RFRH0zSZ4C&pg=PA89&hl=fr&source=gbs_toc_r&cad=4#v=onepage&q&f=false| author=Alex McKay| page=91| year=2001}}</ref><ref name="Liverpool" />
In 1908, he was appointed Political Officer in [[Sikkim]]. He soon became very influential in [[Sikkim#Government and politics|Sikkimese]] and [[Bhutanese politics]], and in 1910 he met the [[13th Dalai Lama]], who had been forced into temporary exile by the Chinese. He got to know him quite well, and later wrote his biography (''Portrait of the Dalai Lama'', published in 1946).
In 1913 he participated in the [[Simla Convention]], a treaty between Great Britain, China and Tibet concerning the status of Tibet. Before the summit, he met in [[Gyantse]] with [[Paljor Dorje Shatra]], the Tibetan representative to the [[British Raj]] at [[Darjeeling]] and advised him to bring to [[Shimla|Simla]] with him all documents concerning relations between [[Tibetan sovereignty debate|China and Tibet]], as well as Tibetan claims to land occupied by China. Bell was designated to assist the Tibetans in the negotiations, with Archibald Rose assigned to be his counterpart for the Chinese. He was appointed a [[Order of St Michael and St George|Companion of the Order of St Michael and St George (CMG)]] in the [[1915 New Year Honours]] for his services.
In 1919 he resigned as Britain's political officer in Sikkim to devote himself full-time to his research. However, London sent him to [[Lhasa]] in 1920 as a special ambassador.<ref>{{citation| author=Michael and Barbara Foster|title=Forbidden Journey: the life of [[Alexandra David-Neel]] | publisher=Harper & Row |year=1987 |ISBN= 9780062503459}}</ref>
After travelling through Tibet and visiting [[Lhasa]] in 1920, he retired to [[Oxford]], where he wrote a series of books on the history, culture and religion of Tibet. He was awarded a knighthood for his Lhasa Mission in 1922.<ref name="Liverpool" />
Palhese, Bell's Tibetan friend and confidant travelled to England in 1927-28 to assist him in editing several of these books.<ref name="Liverpool">[http://www.liverpoolmuseums.org.uk/collections/item.aspx?tab=people&item=50.31.132&coll=1&mat=35&page=1&expand=51034 Portrait of Sir Charles Bell CMG KCIE], National Museums Liverpool.</ref> [[File:13th Dalai Lama, Sir Charles Bell and Maharaj Kumar Sidkeong Trul-ku.jpg|thumb|324x324px|[[13th Dalai Lama|The 13th Dalai Lama]] (right), Sir Charles Bell (left), and [[Sidkeong Tulku Namgyal|Maharaj Kumar Sidkeong Tulku]] (center) in Calcutta around March 1910.]] Some of the photographs that he took in Tibet can be found in the [[Pitt Rivers Museum]] in Oxford. Some of these were included in the 1997 book ''Tibet: Caught in Time''.
His English-Tibetan colloquial dictionary was first published in 1905 together with a grammar of colloquial Tibetan as ''Manual of Colloquial Tibetan''.
[[Peter Fleming (writer)|Peter Fleming]] mentions Bell in the introduction to the book ''[[Seven Years in Tibet]]'' by [[Heinrich Harrer]], Flamingo imprint 1997, specifically his surprisingly close relationship to the 13th Dalai Lama even though he was a foreigner.
==References==
{{Reflist}}
== Works == *''Manual of Colloquial Tibetan''. Calcutta: Baptist Mission Press, 1905. (Part II, English-Tibetan vocabulary; later editions 1919 and 1939) *''Portrait of a Dalai Lama: the Life and Times of the Great Thirteenth'' by Charles Alfred Bell, Sir Charles Bell, Publisher: Wisdom Publications (MA), January 1987, {{ISBN|978-0-86171-055-3}} (first published as ''Portrait of the Dalai Lama'': London: Collins, 1946). *''Tibet: Past and Present''. Oxford: Clarendon Press, 1924 *''The People of Tibet''. Oxford: Clarendon Press, 1928 *''The Religion of Tibet''. Oxford: Clarendon Press, 1931 *''Tibet: Caught in Time''. Reading: Garnet, 1997. Contains photographs by Charles Bell and John Claude White
== External links == *[http://tibet.prm.ox.ac.uk/photo_1998.285.137.1.html the Tibet Album, British photography in Central Tibet 1920 - 1950] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20080717053904/http://tibet.prm.ox.ac.uk/publication_%27The%2BPeople%2Bof%2BTibet%27%2C%2BSir%2BCharles%2BBell%2C%2BOxfo.html List of illustrations from 'The People of Tibet', Sir Charles Bell, Oxford: Clarendon Press, 1928] *[http://www.npg.org.uk/live/search/portrait.asp?LinkID=mp62245&rNo=1&role=sit Photo]
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Bell, Charles Alfred}} [[Category:Tibetologists]] [[Category:1870 births]] [[Category:1945 deaths]] [[Category:Ambassadors to Tibet]] [[Category:Companions of the Order of St Michael and St George]] [[Category:Knights Commander of the Order of the Indian Empire]] [[Category:Alumni of New College, Oxford]] [[Category:People of British India]]
