This is a list of [[blackface]] [[minstrel show|minstrel]] troupes.
* [[John H. Lee (musician)|Adams and Lee]]<ref>October and November 1890, ''S.S.Stewart's Banjo and Guitar Journal''.</ref> * [[Kingfisher (clipper)#Life aboard ship|Backus' Minstrels]] * [[Brooker and Clayton's Georgia Minstrels]]<ref name="toll-199">{{cite book| last=Toll| first=Robert C.| year=1974| title=Blacking Up: The Minstrel Show in Nineteenth-century America| location=New York| publisher=Oxford University Press| page=199}}: an all-black minstrel troupe.</ref> * [[Bryant's Minstrels]]<ref name="toll-57">Toll, 1974, p. 57.</ref> * [[Buckley's Serenaders]] (a.k.a. Buckley's Congo Melodists, Buckley's New Orleans Serenaders, New Orleans Serenaders)<ref name="lott-180">{{cite book| last=Lott| first=Eric| title=Love and Theft: Blackface Minstrelsy and the American Working Class| publisher=Oxford University Press| year=1993| isbn=0-19-509641-X| page=180}}</ref> * [[Callender's Georgia Minstrels]]<ref name="toll-200">Toll, 1974, p. 200.</ref> * [[Campbell's Minstrels]]<ref name="lott-180" /> * [[Christy Minstrels]] (a.k.a. George Christy Minstrels)<ref name="lott-180" /> * [[Duprez & Benedict's Minstrels]] * [[Ethiopian Serenaders]] (a.k.a. Boston Minstrels, Ethiopian Melodists, Ethiopian Minstrels)<ref name="toll-37">Toll, 1974, p. 37-8.</ref> * [[Gavitt's Original Ethiopian Serenaders]]<ref name="lott-37">Lott, 1993, p. 37: an all-black minstrel troupe.</ref> * [[The Black and White Minstrel Show|George Mitchell Minstrels]] * [[Georgia Minstrels]], later [[Haverly's European Minstrels]]<ref name="Peterson1997">{{cite book|author=Bernard L. Peterson|title=The African American Theatre Directory, 1816-1960: A Comprehensive Guide to Early Black Theatre Organizations, Companies, Theatres, and Performing Groups|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pH2npoewU5cC&pg=PA38|year=1997|publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group|isbn=978-0-313-29537-9|page=38}}</ref> * [[Haverly's United Mastodon Minstrels]]<ref name="toll-146">Toll, 1974, p. 146.</ref> * [[Kunkel's Nightingales]]<ref name="Mahar 362">Mahar 362.</ref> * [[Madame Rentz's Female Minstrels]]<ref name="toll-138">Toll, 1974, p. 138: an all-female minstrel troupe.</ref> * [[Ole Bull Band of Serenaders]]<ref name="Mahar 362"/> * [[Ordway's Aeolians]]<ref name="Mahar 362"/> * [[Sable Brothers and Sisters]]<ref name="Mahar 363">Mahar 363.</ref> * [[Sable Harmonists]]<ref name="Mahar 363"/> * [[San Francisco Minstrels]]<ref>{{cite news|last1=McCoy|first1=Sharon D.|title="The Trouble Begins at Eight": Mark Twain, the San Francisco Minstrels, and the Unsettling Legacy of Blackface Minstrelsy|url=https://muse.jhu.edu/article/260994/pdf|accessdate=10 May 2016|work=American Literary Realism|pages=232–248|doi=10.1353/alr.0.0022}}</ref> * [[Sanford's Opera Troupe]] (a.k.a. Sanford's Minstrels)<ref>Mahar 359–60.</ref> * [[Virginia Minstrels]] (a.k.a. Virginia Serenaders)<ref name="lott-180" /> * [[White's Serenaders]] (a.k.a. White's Minstrels)<ref>Mahar 359.</ref> * [[Wood's Minstrels]] (a.k.a. Christy and Wood's Minstrels)<ref>Mahar 360.</ref>
==See also== * [[List of entertainers known to have performed in blackface]]
==References== <references />
[[Category:Blackface minstrel troupes| ]] [[Category:Arts-related lists|Blackface minstrel troupes]]

{{ about|collecting hobbies|other hobbies|List of hobbies}} {{Collecting Hobby}} This is a list of '''popular collectables''' described in Wikipedia articles. The references cited include collector's clubs and societies for each item to support its presence on this list by demonstrating the notability and/or popularity of the collectible.
== Advertising collectibles == : ''For '''print advertisements''', see the section [[List of collectibles#Books, magazines, and paper|Books, magazines, and paper]] below.''
* [[Advertising]] collectables<ref>[http://www.pastimes.org/ Antique Advertising Association of America]</ref> * [[Phillumeny]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.phillumeny.com/|title=British Matchbox Label and Booklet Society working for Phillumeny|publisher=|accessdate=1 February 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://nwp.phillumeny.com/|title=North Western Phillumenists|publisher=|accessdate=1 February 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wmmls.co.uk/|title=wmmls.co.uk|publisher=|accessdate=1 February 2015}}</ref> ** [[Matchbook]]s<ref>[http://www.matchcovers.net/ American Matchcover Collecting Club]</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.matchcover.org/|title=Rathkamp Matchcover Society|publisher=|accessdate=1 February 2015}}</ref> ** [[Matchbox]]es<ref>[**http://www.matchbox-labels.co.uk**/{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} This site no longer exists]</ref> ([[Phillumeny]]) * [[Premium (marketing)|Premiums]] ** [[Radio premiums]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.otrr.org/Pages/Publications/magz_radio_premium_collectors_newsletter.htm|title=Old Time Radio Researchers Group|publisher=|accessdate=1 February 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.reproalert.com/|title=Radio Premium Exchange REPRO ALERT!|publisher=|accessdate=1 February 2015}}</ref> * [[Prize (marketing)|Prizes]] ** [[Bazooka Joe]] comics from [[Bazooka (chewing gum)|Bazooka bubble gum]] ** [[Cereal box prize]]s *** [[Crater Critters]] ** [[Cracker Jack]] prizes ** [[Pin-back button]]s ** [[Tazos]] from [[Frito Lay]] products
=== Brandname products=== * [[Avon Products|Avon]] * [[Campbell's Soup]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.soupclan.com/|title=CC International Home Page|publisher=|accessdate=1 February 2015}}</ref> * [[Coca-Cola]] * [[Disneyana]] ** [[Disney pin trading]] * [[Harley Davidson]] * [[John Deere]] * [[Maytag]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.isasc.org/|title=ISASC|publisher=|accessdate=1 February 2015}}</ref> * [[McDonald's]] * [[Ronson's Lighters]] * [[Zippo]] lighters * [[Luxury goods]]
=== See also === * [[List of American advertising characters]] * [[List of Australian and New Zealand advertising characters]] * [[List of European advertising characters]]
==Architectural== {{Portal|Architecture}} * [[Fireplace]] * [[Furniture]] * [[Household hardware|Hardware]] * [[Lighting]], [[Lamp (fixture)|lamps]], [[lampshades]] * [[Lock (security device)|Locks]] and [[Key (lock)|keys]] * [[Tile]]
==Art== {{Portal|Visual arts|Photography}} * [[Art valuation|Valuable works of art]] * [[Cultural artifact|Artifacts]] * [[Folk Art]] * [[Indigenous peoples of the Americas|Native American]] art * [[Photograph]]s * [[Printmaking|Prints]]
==Books, magazines, and paper== * [[Advertisement]]s ** [[Absolut vodka]] ads ** [[Got Milk?]] ads * [[Autograph]]s * [[Map collection|Map collecting]] ** [[Globe]]s ** [[Map|Roadmaps]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.roadmaps.org/|title=Road Map Collectors Association - Road Map Collectors Association|publisher=|accessdate=1 February 2015}}</ref> * [[Paperweight]]s * [[Sticker (paper)]]
=== Books and periodicals === {{Portal|Books|Children's literature|Literature}} * [[Book collecting|Books]] ** [[Children's literature]] ** [[First edition]]s {{Portal|Comics|Anime and Manga}} * [[Comic book collecting|Comic books]] ** [[List of DC Archive Editions|DC reprints]] ** [[Marvel Masterworks#Table of Marvel Masterworks|Marvel reprints]] ** [[Manga]] * [[Magazine]]s * [[Magazine clipping]]s * [[Newspapers]]
=== Cards === * [[Artist trading cards]] * [[Phone-card collecting|Phone-cards]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://steveon2.tripod.com/index.html|title=Shannonside CallCard Collectors Club - Website Ver 2.0|publisher=|accessdate=1 February 2015}}</ref><ref>[http://www.telekortsamlarna.com/eng/ Swedish Phonecard Collectors' Society] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120331084636/http://www.telekortsamlarna.com/eng/ |date=2012-03-31 }}</ref> * [[Playing card]]s ** [[Joker (playing card)|Jokers]] ** [[Tarot|Tarot cards]] * [[Postcard]]s * [[Trade card]]s ** [[Cigarette card]]s ** [[Tea culture#Tea cards|Tea cards]] * [[Trading card]]s ** [[Insert cards]] ** [[Non-sports trading card|Non-sports cards]] ** [[Sports card]]s *** [[Baseball card]]s *** [[Basketball card]]s *** [[Football card (North America)|Football cards]] *** [[Hockey card]]s *** [[Jersey cards]]
=== Ephemera === [[Ephemera]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ephemerasociety.org/|title=Ephemera Society of America|publisher=|accessdate=1 February 2015}}</ref> is transitory written and printed matter not intended to be retained or preserved. Some collectable ephemera is listed below. * [[Air sickness bag]]s * [[Bookmark]]s * [[Brochure]]s and [[Guide book]]s * [[Tyrosemiophilia|Cheese labels]] * [[Greeting cards]] * [[Door hanger|Hotel Do Not Disturb signs]] * [[Lotology|Lottery tickets]] * [[Matchboxes]] * [[Ticket (admission)|Movie tickets]] * [[Newsletter]]s * [[Passport]]s * [[Pamphlet]]s * [[Postcard]]s * [[Posters]] * [[Public transport timetable]]s ** [[Airline timetable]]s ** [[Public transport timetable]]s ** [[Railroad timetable]]s * [[Sucrology|Sugar sachets]] * [[Tea bag|Tea bag labels]] * [[Tea bag|Tea bag wrappers]] * [[Ticket (admission)|Ticket]]s
==Clothing, fabric, and textiles== {{Portal|Textile arts|Fashion|Knitting}} * [[Brooch]]es * [[Button collecting|Buttons]] * [[Handbag collecting|Handbag]]s * [[Lapel pin]]s * Masquerade [[mask]]s * [[Needlework]] * [[Quilt]]s * [[Patch collecting|Scutelliphily]]: [[Patch collecting|Patches]] and [[badge]]s * [[Sewing]] * [[Textile]]s * [[Thimble]]s * [[Vintage clothing]] and accessories
==Coins, currency, and stamps== {{Portal|Numismatics|Philately}} * [[Numismatics]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.money.org/|title=Home|publisher=|accessdate=1 February 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://numismatics.org/|title=American Numismatic Society - Main / Home Page|publisher=|accessdate=1 February 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.numis.org/|title=- Numismatics International - Celebrating 50 Years|publisher=|accessdate=1 February 2015}}</ref> ** [[Coin collecting]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chicagocoinclub.org/|title=Chicago Coin Club|publisher=|accessdate=1 February 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://dbouge.tripod.com/|title=Silver Dollar Club|author=Dan Bouge|publisher=|accessdate=1 February 2015}}</ref> ** [[Notaphily]] — Paper currency<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.spmc.org/|title=SPMC|publisher=|accessdate=1 February 2015}}</ref> ** [[Exonumia]] *** [[Token coin]]s ** [[Scripophily]] *** [[Bond (finance)|Bonds]] *** [[Stock]]s * [[Philately]]<ref>[http://aps.org.au/xoops/ Australian Philatelic Society] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120426211908/http://aps.org.au/xoops/ |date=2012-04-26 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bnaps.org/|title=BNAPS|publisher=|accessdate=1 February 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rpsc.org/|title=The Royal Philatelic Society of Canada|publisher=|accessdate=1 February 2015}}</ref> ** [[Duck stamp|Federal duck stamp]]s<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ndscs.org/|title=National Duck Stamp Collectors Society Web Page|publisher=|accessdate=1 February 2015}}</ref> ** [[First day cover]]s<ref>[http://www.afdcs.org/ American First Day Cover Society]</ref> ** [[Postmarks]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.postmarks.org/|title=Welcome to the Post Mark Collectors Club!|publisher=|accessdate=1 February 2015}}</ref> ** [[Stamp collecting]]
==Film and television== {{Portal|Film|Television}} * [[DVD]]s * [[DVD player]]s * [[Blu-ray]]s * [[Film]]s * [[Film memorabilia]] * [[Film prop]]s * [[Movie poster]]s * [[Television show]]s * [[Laser disc]]s * [[Universal Media Disc]]s * [[Betamax]] tapes * [[VHS|Videocassette tape]]s * [[Videocassette recorder|VCR]]s * [[Video CD|VCD]]s
==Glass and pottery==

==Theme== A theme collection includes related or unrelated items that have a unifying theme or common thread<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.paperweight.org/#theme|title=Paperweight Collectors Association, Inc.|publisher=|accessdate=1 February 2015}}</ref> or a collection which fits the scope of a special interest.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blog.rarenewspapers.com/?p=2036|title=Collectible themes… additional thoughts…|publisher=|accessdate=1 February 2015}}</ref> Items in a theme collection might include anything that has a certain company logo, has an image or shape of a specific theme. Besides the examples below, there are many theme collections within certain fields. For example, a theme collection can consist of postage stamps with images of butterflies or paper dolls with a wedding theme. For collectables related to a person, organization, event or media, see the [[List of collectibles#Memorabilia|Memorabilia]] section above.

revision.text:
[[File:Ma’oz Hayyim.JPG|250px|thumbnail|Ma’oz Hayyim Synagogue]] The '''Maoz Haim Synagogue''' was originally constructed in the 3rd century as a simple [[Byzantine]]-era type [[basilica]] building, later apsidical, in the [[Beit She'an]] region in northern [[Israel]]. Discovered in February 1974 by Mr. A. Ya’aqobi during some unrelated digging near [[Maoz Haim]], it stands out as an unusual archeological find that contains a record of synagogue development from a time of otherwise sparse historiography. It was even developing right through times of anti-Judaic legislation and sermonizing.<ref>Levine, Lee. The Ancient Synagogue: The First Thousand Years, 211</ref> The [[synagogue]] was located amongst a large settlement in which it served as a center of worship for [[Jews]] there from its beginning up through its final destruction by fire sometime in the early 7th century.<ref name=Levine89>Levine, Lee, ed. Ancient Synagogues Revealed, 89</ref>
==Layout== The initial layout began as a fourteen by twelve and a half meter square room with two rows of five columns with benches lining the walls, although none remained standing.<ref>אפרים שטרן. אנציקלופדיה החדשה לחפירות ארכיאולוגית בארץ ישראל</ref> There was a single entrance eastward which is considered to be unusual. Most synagogues, aside from others which were located in the same northern Galil region, did not share this feature. However, it is mentioned in rabbinic sources as part of the synagogue layout in order to emulate the eastward entrance utilized by the [[Tabernacle]].<ref>Levine, Lee. The Ancient Synagogue: The First Thousand Years, 199</ref> The focal point of the synagogue was located southward, towards [[Jerusalem]]. Such an orientation had not previously been a feature of synagogues of the era, but was a new custom which was just beginning to take hold.<ref>Levine, Lee. The Ancient Synagogue: The First Thousand Years, 195</ref> This is especially noticeable with remodeling which was done in the 4th century, altering the synagogue to feature an apse in the southern wall. While the synagogue did not originally have a narthex, one was added during the later phases of building to the north, although it was totally destroyed. The later phases also added an additional entrance to the north, presumably to allow for easier access to the sanctuary.
==Apse== The apse, where the Torah Shrine had previously stood in the first phase of the synagogue, was further modified in the 6th century to include a raised platform enclosed by a [[chancel screen]] which may have been used to emphasize the sanctity of the Torah shrine area as compared to the rest of the synagogue or the congregation.<ref>Fine, Steven. This Holy Place: On the Sanctity of the Synagogue During the Greco-Roman Period, 222</ref> Such separations were very common in ancient synagogues and the raised [[bima]] area is what shows that this was no exception.<ref>Levine, Lee, ed. Ancient Synagogues Revealed, 87</ref> The area of the screen depicted a menorah as well as [[Hebrew]] letters. The only Hebrew word in the entire building was [[Shalom]]; the remainder of the inscriptions were in [[Greek language|Greek]].
Behind the bima there was an area, possibly a geniza, in which several coins, pottery, and glass were found, which were amongst the few artifacts that were found at all at the site. The coins themselves were from the Byzantine era and helped identify the stages of building and development. More coins, fifty in all, were found outside the southern wall which were most likely hidden there amongst broken roof tiles in order to serve as a possible emergency funds, although the original owner never had the chance to claim them.<ref>Levine, Lee, ed. Ancient Synagogues Revealed, 88</ref>
==Mosaic Floor== There were many interesting [[mosaic]]s which were found at the dig site. The only figures found were birds, but there were also many Jewish symbols portrayed in mosaic form, including a [[Menorah (Temple)|menorah]], an [[etrog]], a [[shofar]] and grapes. However, the symbols and birds were covered up in the 7th century, transforming the synagogue into one which was aniconic, likely as an act of piety.<ref>Levine, Lee. The Ancient Synagogue: The First Thousand Years, 367</ref>
In relation to this, the majority of the remaining floor was primarily composed of [[geometric patterns]]. Geometric patterns were popular before as in the earliest layer to an extent, but likely were especially valued in an aniconic society. However, it was not well preserved in the upper layers due to the aforementioned destruction of uncertain cause and additional construction that occurred by the local populace afterwards.<ref name=Levine89/> Despite this, the mosaic floor from the initial stage of construction was better preserved as it had been filled in with approximately 30 centimeters of dirt to lay the new aniconic floor, although not many artifacts were found within it.
== References== {{reflist}}
==Bibliography== *Fine, Steven. This Holy Place: On the Sanctity of the Synagogue During the Greco-Roman Period. (Notre Dame: University of Notre Dame Press, 1998) *Levine, Lee, ed. Ancient Synagogues Revealed. (Jerusalem: Israel Exploration Society, 1981) *Levine, Lee. The Ancient Synagogue: The First Thousand Years. (New Haven: Yale University Press, 2005) *אפרים שטרן. אנציקלופדיה החדשה לחפירות ארכיאולוגית בארץ ישראל. (הוצאת כרטא, 1992)
==External links== *[http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-3309730,00.html Mosaic Pictures on Ynet]

revision.text:
The '''Mappae clavicula''' is a medieval Latin text containing manufacturing recipes for crafts materials, including for metals, glass, mosaics, and dyes and tints for materials. The information and style in the recipes is very terse. Each recipe consists of the names of the ingredients and typically about two sentences on combining the ingredients together. A small minority of the recipes go to about six sentences. The text comes with a short preamble, and other than that it is just recipes. The number of recipes was expanded over the course of the medieval centuries, and some medieval copies have deletions as well as additions, so it is better thought of as a family of texts with a largely common core, not a single text. Most of the ''Mappae Clavicula'' recipes are also in medieval Latin in a text known as the ''Compositiones ad Tingenda'' (English: "Recipes for Coloring (or Tingeing)").<ref>[https://www.jstor.org/stable/2848238 "Notes on Some Manuscripts of the ''Mappae Clavicula''"], by Rozelle P. Johnson, year 1935. [https://www.jstor.org/stable/226251 A Review of ''Compositiones variae'' from Codex 490, Biblioteca Capitolare], by Lynn White, year 1940. [https://books.google.com/books?id=rB3cIVVq-YUC&pg=PA32 ''Books of Secrets in Medieval and Early Modern Culture''], by William Eamon, year 1996, pages 32-36.</ref>
== Origin and accretion == The core was probably originally compiled around AD 600, perhaps in [[Alexandria]] in Egypt, in Greek. The core contains items traceable to earlier Alexandrian Greek texts, particularly the [[Papyrus Graecus Holmiensis|Stockholm papyrus]] and [[Leyden papyrus X|Leiden Papyrus X]], which are Greek texts dated to the 2nd or 3rd century AD that contain some of the same and similar recipes. The first few recipes in the Phillipps-Corning manuscript<ref name=PhillippsCorning /> of the ''Mappae clavicula'' were long considered integral, but they form a distinct separate entity, the ''De coloribus et mixtionibus'', which survives (in whole or in part) in at least 62 manuscripts.<ref name=Clarke>Clarke, M. (2001) ''The Art of All Colours: Mediaeval Recipe Books for Painters and Illuminators''. London: Archetype Publications.</ref> The core of the Latin ''Mappae clavicula'' is very likely a translation of a Greek text, although the original Greek text (if it existed) does not exist today.
The best manuscripts of the ''Mappae clavicula'' date from the eighth to the twelfth century.<ref name=Clarke /><ref>Smith, C. S. and J. G. Hawthorne (1974) ‘Mappae Clavicula: A Little Key to the World of Medieval Techniques’, ''Transactions of the American Philosophical Society: Held at Philadelphia for promoting useful knowledge'' (new series) 64 (4) [occupies whole issue].</ref>
One of the fullest collections of recipes is in a certain manuscript dated late 12th century in which about 300 recipes are presented. In this manuscript, called the Phillipps-Corning manuscript, some of the names for some materials are Arabic names (e.g. ''alquibriz'' from the Arabic for sulphur, ''atincar'' from the Arabic for borax, ''alcazir'' from the Arabic for tin).<ref name=PhillippsCorning>[https://archive.org/stream/archaeologiaormi32sociuoft#page/187/mode/1up ''Mappae clavicula'' from a 12th-century manuscript], text published in Latin by Thomas Phillipps in year 1847. The original manuscript that Thomas Phillipps possessed, dated late 12th century, is now in the hands of the Corning Museum of Glass. Hence it is referred to as "the Phillipps-Corning manuscript". A digital image of it is downloadable at the [http://www.cmog.org/library/manuscript-mappae-clavicula Corning Museum of Glass, MS 5].</ref> The recipes containing the Arabic names are historically later, and are in all likelihood no earlier than the 12th century. Certain earlier manuscripts have about 200 recipes.
The principal manuscripts are: * The ''Lucca MS'', Lucca, Biblioteca Capitolare Feliniana, Codex 490, the oldest witness, c. 800. * The Sélestat MS, Sélestat, Bibliothèque Humaniste, MS 17. A very full yet old witness, early ninth century. * The ''Codex Matritensis'' ('Madrid codex'), Madrid, Biblioteca Nacional, MS A.16 (Was: MS A.19), c. 1130. * The Phillipps-Corning Manuscript, Corning Museum of Glass, MS 5, late twelfth century.<ref name=PhillippsCorning />
These are simply among the fullest [[Textual criticism|witnesses]] - there are dozens more that preserve extracts.<ref name=Clarke />
== Title == The title, ''Mappae clavicula'', is absurd, translating approximately as 'the little key to the small cloth'. The best explanation is that it is a mis-translation from a Greek original, in which χειρόκμητον ''kheirókmēton'' ('knack' or 'trick of the trade') was mis-read as χειρόμακτρον ''kheirómaktron'' ('hand-towel').<ref>Robert Halleux, 'Recettes d'artisan, recettes d'alchimiste', in: R. Jansen-Sieben (ed.) ''Artes mechanicae'', Archives et bibliothèques de Belgique, no. spécial 34 (Brussels, 1989), p. 28</ref> This is consistent with the observation that certain recipes derive from the Greek technical papyri, the [[Leyden papyrus X]] and the [[Papyrus Graecus Holmiensis|Stockholm papyrus]].
== References == {{Reflist}}
* Sir Thomas Phillipps, "A transcript of a manuscript treatise on the preparation of pigments, and on various processes of the decorative arts practised during the Middle Ages, written in the twelfth century, and entitled ''Mappae Clavicula''." Published in journal ''Archaeologia'', volume XXXII, pages 183–244, year 1847. [https://archive.org/stream/archaeologiaormi32sociuoft#page/183/mode/1up Downloadable at Archive.org]. * [[Cyril Stanley Smith|C. S. Smith]] and [[John G. Hawthorne|J. G. Hawthorne]] (1974) ‘Mappae Clavicula: A Little Key to the World of Medieval Techniques’, ''Transactions of the American Philosophical Society: Held at Philadelphia for promoting useful knowledge'' (new series) 64 (4) [occupies whole issue].
== External links == * [https://archive.org/stream/archaeologiaormi32sociuoft#page/187/mode/1up ''Mappae Clavicula'' (in Latin), a late 12th century version]. (Retrieved 17 July 2014) * [http://www.cmog.org/library/manuscript-mappae-clavicula ''Mappae Clavicula'' (in Latin)], possibly written in Flanders, c. 1150. Held at the Rakow Research Library of the Corning Museum of Glass. (Retrieved 17 July 2014) * [http://www.elizabethancostume.net/dyes/mappae.html Dye Recipes in English from the ''Mappae Clavicula''], translated by [[Cyril Stanley Smith]] and [[John G. Hawthorne]]. Only dye recipes. (Retrieved 17 July 2014)
{{italic title}}

{{Infobox prison | prison_name = Men's Central Jail (MCJ) | location = [[Los Angeles, California]] | coordinates = {{Coord|34.0590|N|118.2321|W|type:landmark_region:US-CA|display=inline,title}} | status = Operational | classification = Minimum - Maximum | capacity = 5,276 | population = 4,300<ref name="losangelestimes">{{cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/local/lanow/la-me-ln-county-jail-plan-20150609-story.html|title=County supervisors vote to reconsider size of new Men's Central Jail|author=Abby Sewell|date=9 June 2015|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|accessdate=24 August 2015}}</ref> | opened = 1963 | managed_by = [[Los Angeles County Sheriff's Department]] | director = Chuck Antuna, Captain }} '''Men's Central Jail''' is a [[Los Angeles County Sheriff's Department]] county jail for men in [[Los Angeles]], [[Los Angeles County, California]], United States. Built in 1963, it is one of the oldest [[county jail]]s in California. The Men's Central Jail is located at 441 Bauchet St., Los Angeles 90012. The Men's Central Jail houses men who are awaiting trial or who have been convicted of crimes.
The Men's Central Jail is considered one of the largest jails in the world.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ktla.com/2015/06/09/county-supervisors-vote-to-reconsider-size-of-new-mens-central-jail/|title=County Supervisors Vote to Reconsider Size of New Men’s Central Jail - KTLA|work=[[KTLA]]|accessdate=4 August 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| author =Jennifer Medina| title =Report Details Wide Abuse in Los Angeles Jail System| quote =| newspaper =[[The New York Times]]| date =September 28, 2011| url =https://www.nytimes.com/2011/09/28/us/aclu-suit-details-wide-abuse-in-los-angeles-jail-system.html| accessdate = August 4, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.scpr.org/news/2015/02/02/49608/county-jail-populations-across-california-dip-afte/|title=Infographic: County jail populations across California dip after Prop 47 - 89.3 KPCC|author=Don Thompson, [[Associated Press]]|work=[[Southern California Public Radio]]|accessdate=4 August 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.laweekly.com/news/in-the-gay-wing-of-la-mens-central-jail-its-not-shanks-and-muggings-but-hand-sewn-gowns-and-tears-5218552|title=Inside the Gay Wing of Men's Central Jail - L.A. Weekly|author=Ani Ucar|work=[[LA Weekly]]|accessdate=4 August 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://abc7.com/archive/9453411/|title=Cell breakouts, attacks 'easy' in outdated Men's Central Jail|work=[[KABC-TV|ABC7 Los Angeles]]|accessdate=4 August 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/local/lanow/la-me-ln-county-jail-plan-20150609-story.html|title=County supervisors vote to reconsider size of new Men's Central Jail|author=Los Angeles Times|date=9 June 2015|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|accessdate=4 August 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2015/06/03/us-usa-jailriot-losangeles-idUSKBN0OJ2UR20150603|title=At least one inmate stabbed in riot at Los Angeles jail|work=Reuters|accessdate=4 August 2015}}</ref> In May 2013, along with the adjacent [[Twin Towers Correctional Facility]], Men's Central Jail was ranked as one of the ten worst prisons in the United States, based on reporting in [[Mother Jones (magazine)|''Mother Jones'']] magazine.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.motherjones.com/politics/2013/05/10-worst-prisons-america-la-county-jail-twin-towers|title=America's 10 Worst Prisons: LA County|work=[[Mother Jones (magazine)|Mother Jones]]|author=James Ridgeway and Jean Casella|date=8 May 2013|accessdate=4 August 2015}}</ref>
==Construction and population== The construction of the Men's Central Jail was finished in 1963. The original building was designed to house 3,323 inmates.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.scpr.org/news/2010/05/05/14795/las-mens-central-jail-plagued-overcrowding-unsanit/|title=LA's Men's Central Jail plagued by overcrowding, unsanitary conditions, violence|author=Southern California Public Radio|work=[[Southern California Public Radio]]|accessdate=24 August 2015}}</ref> In 1976, an addition was added to the structure at the cost of $35 million,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailynews.com/general-news/20111212/upkeep-is-proving-costly-as-mens-central-jail-shows-its-age|title=Upkeep is proving costly as Men's Central Jail shows its age|work=[[Los Angeles Daily News]]|accessdate=24 August 2015}}</ref> and by December 1990, inmate capacity was 5,276.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1990-12-16/news/mn-9280_1_men-s-central-jail|title=L.A. COUNTY'S CENTRAL JAIL : Overcrowding and Age Burden Facility|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|accessdate=24 August 2015}}</ref>
Men's Central Jail has severe [[overcrowding]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1997-03-14/local/me-38194_1_jail-overcrowding|title=ACLU Criticizes Jail Overcrowding|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|accessdate=24 August 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailynews.com/social-affairs/20140621/mens-central-jail-overcrowding-crisis-could-cost-17-billion-to-fix|title=Men’s Central Jail overcrowding crisis could cost $1.7 billion to fix|work=[[Los Angeles Daily News]]|accessdate=24 August 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailynews.com/20090415/aclu-calls-mens-central-jail-a-dungeon-seeks-closure|title=ACLU calls Men's Central Jail a dungeon, seeks closure|work=[[Los Angeles Daily News]]|author=Troy Anderson|date=15 April 2009|accessdate=24 August 2015}}</ref> In June 2015, the inmate population was about 17,000<ref name="losangelestimes"/> and in March 1997, the inmate population was about 13,000.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1997-03-01/local/me-33735_1_jail-population|title=ACLU Demands Meeting as Jail Crowding Soars|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|accessdate=24 August 2015}}</ref>
===Notable inmates=== * [[Chris Brown]], recording artist<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20797761,00.html|title=Chris Brown Ordered to Remain in Jail|work=[[People (magazine)|People]]|accessdate=5 August 2015}}</ref> * [[Suge Knight]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ew.com/article/2003/02/26/suge-knight-released-jail|title=Suge Knight is released from jail|work=[[Entertainment Weekly]]'s EW.com|accessdate=5 August 2015}}</ref> * [[Todd Bridges]], actor, ''[[Diff'rent Strokes]]''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1989-11-10/local/me-1148_1_todd-bridges|title=Mistrial Declared in Bridges' Assault Case|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|accessdate=5 August 2015}}</ref> * [[Sean Penn]], actor<ref>https://www.nytimes.com/2002/11/16/us/a-celebrity-home-that-s-not-on-the-star-maps.html</ref> * [[Kelsey Grammer]], actor<ref name="nytimes.com">https://www.nytimes.com/2002/11/16/us/a-celebrity-home-that-s-not-on-the-star-maps.html</ref><ref name="people.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20124097,00.html|title=The Party's Over|work=[[People (magazine)|People]]|accessdate=5 August 2015}}</ref> * [[Richard Pryor]], comedian<ref name="nytimes.com"/> * [[Tommy Lee]], [[Mötley Crüe]]'s [[drummer]]<ref name="nytimes.com"/> * [[Scott Weiland]]<ref name="nytimes.com"/> * [[Lyle and Erik Menendez|Erik Menendez]]<ref name="people.com"/> * [[Richard Ramirez]]<ref name="nytimes.com"/> * [[O.J. Simpson]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2002/nov/21/usa|title=Room 7201: celebrity confinement California style|work=[[The Guardian]]|accessdate=5 August 2015}}</ref> * [[Shorty Rossi]], reality TV personality, ''[[Pit Boss (TV series)|Pit Boss]]''<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MOk5DQd59w4C&pg=PA64&lpg=PA64&dq=shorty+rossi+%22men's+central+jail%22&source=bl&ots=fy5LtZCIhB&sig=Ql09Xm6tRv7Tstw2ioHw5vtPnG4&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CCUQ6AEwAWoVChMI8JDb1IqSxwIVwR0eCh2DkQqX#v=onepage&q=shorty%20rossi%20%22men's%20central%20jail%22&f=false|title=Four Feet Tall and Rising|work=google.com|accessdate=5 August 2015}}</ref> * [[Phil Spector]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.neontommy.com/2009/04/aclu-urges-supervisors-to-clos}}</ref>
==Services== Men’s Central Jail provides some services to its inmates. Inmates can attend self-help classes on [[domestic violence]], [[alcohol abuse]], and [[substance abuse]]. Religious services are provided to inmates in the wake of several [[ACLU]] lawsuits.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailynews.com/social-affairs/20140328/aclu-says-muslim-inmates-in-la-jails-not-treated-equally|title=ACLU says Muslim inmates in L.A. jails not treated equally|work=[[Los Angeles Daily News]]|author=Thomas Himes|date=28 March 2014|accessdate=4 August 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/local/la-me-adv-jail-ramadan-20140727-story.html|title=Under new rules, Muslim inmates in L.A. County jails observe Ramadan|author=Cindy Chang|date=26 July 2014|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|accessdate=4 August 2015}}</ref> Select inmates now (2004) can earn a [[General Educational Development|GED]] while incarcerated.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2004/apr/07/local/me-jail7|title=Gay Jail Inmates Get Chance to Learn|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|author=James Ricci|date=7 April 2004|accessdate=24 August 2015}}</ref>
==Violence and lawsuits== The ACLU has sued Men's Central Jail for major [[civil rights]] violations.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailynews.com/general-news/20090414/aclu-report-las-mens-central-jail-nightmarish|title=ACLU report: L.A.'s Men's Central Jail 'nightmarish'|work=[[Los Angeles Daily News]]|accessdate=4 August 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2012/jan/19/local/la-me-jails-aclu-20120119|title=L.A. County Sheriff's Department sued by ACLU|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|accessdate=4 August 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.scpr.org/news/2010/05/05/14828/aclu-says-la-county-jail-guard-perpetuate-violence/|title=ACLU: LA County jail guards perpetuate violence|author=Southern California Public Radio|work=[[Southern California Public Radio]]|accessdate=4 August 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.laweekly.com/news/mens-county-jail-visitor-viciously-beaten-by-guards-2170701|title=Men's County Jail Visitor Viciously Beaten by Guards|author=Chris Vogel|work=[[LA Weekly]]|accessdate=4 August 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.aclu.org/feature/la-county-jails|title=LA County Jails|work=[[American Civil Liberties Union]]|accessdate=4 August 2015}}</ref> The [[United States Department of Justice]] has also sued the Men's Central Jail.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.scpr.org/news/2015/08/04/53566/la-sheriff-agrees-to-new-reforms-at-jails-settles/|title=Source: LA Sheriff agrees to new reforms at jails, settles civil DOJ lawsuit|author=Southern California Public Radio|work=[[Southern California Public Radio]]|accessdate=4 August 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.scpr.org/news/2014/06/06/44573/justice-department-threatens-lawsuit-over-mental-h/|title=Los Angeles County's jails operating under unconstitutional conditions, says Justice Department|author=Southern California Public Radio|work=[[Southern California Public Radio]]|accessdate=4 August 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2011/sep/25/local/la-me-fbi-jails-20110925|title=FBI investigating reports of beatings in Los Angeles County jails|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|accessdate=4 August 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://america.aljazeera.com/articles/2015/4/29/la-county-settles-civil-rights-case-with-doj.html|title=LA County Settles Civil Rights Case With DOJ - Al Jazeera America|work=[[Al Jazeera America]]|accessdate=4 August 2015}}</ref>
In 2013, federal prosecutors charged 18 Sheriff's Officers with [[Police brutality|excessive use of force]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/local/lanow/la-me-ln-sheriff-indicted-jail-misconduct-20131209-story.html|title=18 Los Angeles sheriff's officials indicted, accused of abuse, obstruction|author=Robert Faturechi and Jack Leonard|date=9 December 2013|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|accessdate=4 August 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| author =Jennifer Medina| title =U.S. Charges 18 Sheriff’s Officers in Inquiry Into Misconduct at Los Angeles Jails| quote =| newspaper =[[The New York Times]]| date =December 9, 2013| url =https://www.nytimes.com/2013/12/10/us/18-charged-in-inquiry-into-los-angeles-sheriffs-office.html| accessdate = August 5, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/six-l-a-sheriffs-officers-found-guilty-of-obstructing-justice-1404260671|title=Six L.A. Sheriff's Officers Found Guilty of Obstructing Justice|author=Erica E. Phillips|date=2 July 2014|work=[[Wall Street Journal]]|accessdate=4 August 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://fox6now.com/2013/12/10/18-l-a-county-deputies-charged-in-civil-rights-corruption-probe/|title=18 L.A. County deputies charged in civil rights, corruption probe|work=[[WITI (TV)|FOX6Now]]|accessdate=4 August 2015}}</ref> In June 2015, Los Angeles Sheriff's Deputies were found guilty of beating a handcuffed man at the Men's Central Jail.<ref>{{cite news| author =[[Associated Press]]| title =Los Angeles Sheriff's Deputies Found Guilty in Jail Beating| quote =| newspaper =[[The New York Times]]| date =June 24, 2015| url =https://www.nytimes.com/aponline/2015/06/24/us/ap-us-los-angeles-jails-investigation.html| accessdate = August 4, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://ktla.com/2015/06/24/three-l-a-county-deputies-convicted-in-beating-of-jail-visitor/|title=Three L.A. County Deputies Convicted in Beating of Jail Visitor|work=[[KTLA]]|accessdate=4 August 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/local/lanow/la-me-ln-sheriff-deputy-testimony-abuse-trial-20150617-story.html|title=Ex-deputy: L.A. County sheriff's deputies beat jail visitor, then lied|author=Los Angeles Times|date=17 June 2015|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|accessdate=4 August 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.justice.gov/usao-cdca/pr/three-deputy-sheriffs-found-guilty-federal-civil-rights-offense-beating-visitor|title=Three Deputy Sheriffs Found Guilty of Federal Civil Rights Offense in Beating of Visitor at Downtown Los Angeles Jail|work=[[United States Department of Justice]]|accessdate=4 August 2015}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==External links== *[http://shq.lasdnews.net/pages/tgen1.aspx?id=MCF Men's Central Jail], Los Angeles County Sheriff's Dept.
{{Downtown Los Angeles|state=collapsed}}
[[Category:Men's prisons]] [[Category:Jails in California]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Downtown Los Angeles]] [[Category:Government buildings in Los Angeles]] [[Category:Los Angeles County Sheriff's Department]] [[Category:Men in the United States]] [[Category:Government buildings completed in 1963]] [[Category:1963 establishments in California]]

'''Mono-ha''' (もの派) is the name given to a group of 20th-century Japanese artists. The Mono-ha artists explored the encounter between natural and industrial materials, such as stone, steel plates, glass, light bulbs, cotton, sponge, paper, wood, wire, rope, leather, oil, and water, arranging them in mostly unaltered, ephemeral states. The works focus as much on the interdependency of these various elements and the surrounding space as on the materials themselves.
==Origin of the Term “Mono-ha” and its Members==
“Mono-ha” is usually translated in a literal manner, as “School of Things.” The Mono-ha artists regularly assert that “Mono-ha” was a term disparagingly coined by critics (specifically Teruo Fujieda and Toshiaki Minemura in ''Bijutsu Techo'' magazine in 1973) well after they had begun to exhibit their work, and they did not begin as an organized collective. Many of the Mono-ha artists were first exhibited at Tamura and Maki Galleries in Tokyo owned by Nobuo[[(Shinro) Yamagiishi]] who was also an art writer and whose archives are in the collection of [[The National Art Center Tokyo]].
Toshiaki Minemura explains in his 1986 essay “What Was Mono-ha?,” that in terms of their academic background and intellectual exchange, the Mono-ha artists are divided into three groups:<ref>Minemura, Toshiaki. [https://www.kamakura.gallery/mono-ha/minemura-en.html "What was MONO-HA?"], ''MONO-HA'', Kamakura Gallery, 1986, p.6</ref>
# '''"The [[Lee Ufan|Lee]] + [[Tama Art University|Tamabi]] Connection.”''' This comprises [[Nobuo Sekine]], [[Kishio Suga]], Shingo Honda, Katsuhiko Narita and Katsurō Yoshida in the painting department, and [[Susumu Koshimizu]] in the sculpture department at [[Tama Art University]] (aka Tamabi) as well as [[Jiro Takamatsu]] and [[Lee Ufan]], a Korean artist who is a close friend of Sekine. # '''“The [[Tokyo University of the Arts|Geidai Connection]],”''' a group of artists around [[Kōji Enokura]] and Noboru Takayama, who were both graduates of the [[Tokyo University of the Arts]] (aka Geidai), and Hiroshi Fujii and Makoto Habu, who were involved in Mono-ha later on. # '''“The [[Nihon University|Nichidai]] Connection,”''' students from the [[Nihon University]] (aka Nichidai) Fine Arts Department—whose central figure was Noriyuki Haraguchi—also known as the “Yokosuka Group,” due to Haraguchi’s upbringing in Yokosuka and his critique of the local US military presence through his work.<ref>''Kishio Suga''. Los Angeles: Blum & Poe, 2012, p.8</ref>
==Socio-Political Context==
Mono-ha emerged in response to a number of social, cultural and political precedents set in the 1960s. With the exception of Lee Ufan, who was a decade older, most of the Mono-ha artists were just beginning their careers when the violent student protests of 1968–69 occurred.
At the same time, there was much protest against the second extension of the US-Japan Security Treaty (known in abbreviated Japanese as ''[[Anpo]]'') in 1970, binding Japan into providing logistical support for the US war in Vietnam. Coupled with demands for the reversion of [[Okinawa]] by 1972 and the removal of nuclear weapons based there, the climate of protest during this period was symptomatic of a growing distrust of the United States’ intentions towards Asia and its dominant position in the bilateral relationship with Japan. The activism of the “''Anpo'' generation” gave rise to a highly intellectual counterculture that was both critical of US “[[imperialism]]” and acutely self-aware of its Japanese identity.<ref>Munroe, Alexandra. ''Japanese Art After 1945: Scream Against the Sky''. Harry N. Abrams Inc, 1994. p.215</ref>
The Mono-ha artists typically deny involvement with student activist movements at the time, though it is thought that the tense political climate influenced their work, allowing them to grapple with and make sense of their unease and disillusionment with postwar modernity in their different ways.
==Recent Attention in the United States==
In 2012, [[Blum & Poe]] gallery introduced the Mono-ha art into the US with the survey exhibition “Requiem for the Sun: The Art of Mono-ha,” curated by Mika Yoshitake. The gallery has also held solo exhibitions of [[Lee Ufan]], [[Kishio Suga]], [[Susumu Koshimizu]], [[Koji Enokura]], and [[Nobuo Sekine]].
==Phase-Mother Earth== {{Infobox artwork | image_file = | painting_alignment = | image_size = | title = Phase-Mother Earth | alt = | other_language_1 = | other_title_1 = | other_language_2 = | other_title_2 = | artist = Nobuo Sekine | year = 1968, 2008 and 2012 | type = [[earth art]] | height_metric = 2.7 | width_metric = 2.2 | length_metric = | height_imperial = | width_imperial = | length_imperial = | diameter_metric = 2.2 | diameter_imperial = | dimensions = | metric_unit = m| imperial_unit = in<!--don't leave this parameter blank—either don't include it, or include the default in. Not including it will default it to in.--> | italic title = no | city = [[Kobe]], [[Suma Rikyu Park]] | museum = | coordinates = <!-- Only use for the exact coordinates of the artwork itself (and only where known) and not for the coordinates of the museum. Leave blank if coordinates are not known. --> | owner = }}
[[Nobuo Sekine]]'s '''Phase-Mother Earth''' is considered to be the initial work of the Mono-ha movement.<ref>{{cite news |title=Series: 1000 artworks to see before you die |first= |last= |url= https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2008/oct/30/sargent-saxon-serrano?INTCMP=SRCH|newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |date=30 October 2008 |accessdate=2 August 2011}}</ref> Originally created in Suma Rikyu Park in [[Kobe]], and without official permission. The work was re-created in 2008<ref>{{cite journal |last1= Rawlings|first1=Ashley|year= 2008|title=Nobuo Sekine's "Phase-Mother Earth" Under Reconstruction |journal=Art Space Tokyo |volume= |issue= October 28|pages= |publisher= |doi= |url= http://artspacetokyo.com/blog/archives/nobuo_sekines_phase_mother_earth_under_reconstruction/ |accessdate= 31 July 2011}}</ref> and 2012. It was a large cylindrical tower made of packed earth, which was removed from a cylindrical hole with the same shape.
==Members== *[[Jiro Takamatsu]] *[[Nobuo Sekine]] *[[Lee Ufan]] *[[Kishio Suga]] *[[Koji Enokura]] *[[Susumu Koshimizu]] *[[Noboru Takayama]] *[[Katsuhiko Narita]] *[[Noriyuki Haraguchi]] *[[Katsuro Yoshida]] *[[Kenji Inumaki]] *[[Shingo Honda]]
==Bibliography==
*''Japon des avant gardes: 1910–1970''. Paris: Centre Georges Pompidou, 1986. *Chong, Doryun. ''Tokyo 1955–1970: A New Avant-Garde''. New York: Museum of Modern Art, 2012. *Koplos, Janet. ''Contemporary Japanese Sculpture''. New York: Abbeville Press, 1991. *Munroe, Alexandra. ''Japanese Art After 1945: Scream Against the Sky''. New York: Harry N. Abrams Inc, 1994. *Yoshitake, Mika. ''Requiem for the Sun: The Art of Mono-ha''. Los Angeles: Blum & Poe, 2012. *''Kishio Suga''. Los Angeles: Blum & Poe, 2012
==References== {{reflist}}

using the same example as in the 'History' section
revision.text:
{{redirect|New York English|other uses|New York English (disambiguation)}} {{Use mdy dates|date=October 2017}}
'''New York City English''', or '''Metropolitan New York English''',<ref>Morén, Bruce (2000). ''Distinctiveness, Coercion and Sonority: A Unified Theory of Weight''. Routledge. p. 203.</ref> is a regional [[dialect]] of [[American English]] spoken by many people in [[New York City]] and much of its surrounding [[New York metropolitan area|metropolitan area]]. Described by sociolinguist [[William Labov]] as the most recognizable dialect in North America, the dialect is known through its association in the media with many public figures and fictional characters. Its features are most densely concentrated in New York City proper and its immediate suburbs (whose residents often commute to New York City), but they also extend somewhat to the wider metropolitan area and the New York City diaspora in other regions.
The dialect is widely known for its pronunciation system, the [[New York accent]], which comprises a number of both [[conservative (linguistics)|conservative]] and innovative features. Major features of the accent include a [[high vowel|high]], [[diphthong|gliding]] {{IPAc-en|ɔː}} vowel (in words like ''talk'' and ''caught''); a [[phonemic split|split]] of the "short a" vowel {{IPAc-en|æ}} into two separate sounds; variable [[rhoticity in English|dropping of ''r'' sounds]]; and a lack of the ''[[cot-caught merger|cot–caught]]'', ''[[Mary-marry-merry merger|Mary–marry–merry]]'', and ''[[hurry-furry merger|hurry–furry]]'' mergers.
==History== The origins of New York City English are diverse, and the sources of many features are probably not recoverable. New York City English, largely with the same major pronunciation system popularly recognized today, was first reproduced in literature and also scientifically documented in the 1890s.<ref>Mencken, H. L. (1919; reprinted 2012). ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=cIPoCHsgATUC&dq American Language]'', 4th Edition. Knopf Doubleday Publishing Group. p. 367</ref> It was then, and still mostly is, associated with ethnically diverse [[European Americans|European-American]] native-English speakers. New York City English likely evolved from an older English variety that encompassed much of the larger [[Mid-Atlantic States|Mid-Atlantic region]], including the [[Delaware Valley]] (whose [[Mid-Atlantic American English|own dialect]] today centers around [[Philadelphia, Pennsylvania|Philadelphia]] and [[Baltimore, Maryland|Baltimore]]), since the New York City dialect and the Delaware Valley dialectal offshoots all still share certain key features, such as a [[close vowel|high]] {{IPA|{{nobreak|/ɔː/}}}} vowel with a [[diphthong|glide]] (sometimes called the ''aww'' vowel) as well as a [[phonemic split]] of the short ''a'' vowel, {{IPA|{{nobreak|/æ/}}}} (making ''gas'' and ''gap'', for example, have different vowels sounds), though New York City's variants are still unique. Linguist [[William Labov]] has pointed out that a similarly-structured but distinct-sounding short-''a'' split, often called the [[trap–bath split]], is found today in the southern half of England, including London, and that both this short-''a'' split and the New York City's may therefore have a common ancestor originating in the nineteenth century.{{efn|{{Harvp|Labov|Ash|Boberg|2006|p=173}}: "In NYC and the Mid-Atlantic region, short-a is split into a tense and lax class. There is reason to believe that the tense class /æh/ descends from the British /ah/ or 'broad-a' class."}}
New York City became an urban economic power in the eighteenth century, with the city's financial elites maintaining close ties with the British Empire even after the Revolutionary War. According to Labov, New York speakers' [[rhoticity in English|loss of the ''r'' sound after vowels]] (which, incidentally, is not found in the nearby Delaware Valley) is thus an imitation of the [[received pronunciation|prestigious British pronunciation]], consistently starting among the upper classes in New York City in the nineteenth century before spreading to other socioeconomic classes.<ref name="Labov et al., 2006, p. 47">{{Harvp|Labov|Ash|Boberg|2006|p=47}}</ref> This aristocratic, non-rhotic (''r''-dropping) pronunciation can be heard, for instance, in recordings of Presidents [[Theodore Roosevelt|Theodore]] and [[Franklin D. Roosevelt]]. After World War II, social perceptions reversed, and the ''r''-preserving (rhotic) pronunciation became the prestige norm throughout the whole United States; what was once the upper-class pronunciation then became perceived as more of a vernacular one, due to the loss of Britain's imperial status, the [[General American|mainstreaming]] of a more rhotic American accent that originated away from the British-influenced East Coast,<ref>Labov (1966/2006)</ref> and widespread postwar migrations of rhotic speakers directly to New York from other regions of the country.<ref>Sȩn, A. L. (1979). ''{{cite journal |jstor=815156 |title=Archived copy }}'', The English Journal, Vol. 68, No. 8 (Nov. 1979), pp. 52–55</ref> Today, most New York City English is variably rhotic, a remnant of the older non-rhotic pronunciation.
Other vernacular pronunciations, such as the dental ''d'' and ''t'', as well as [[Th-stopping|''th''-stopping]], likely come from contact with foreign languages, particularly Italian and Yiddish, brought into New York City through its huge immigration waves of the past century and before. Grammatical structures, such as the lack of inversion in indirect questions, have the flavor of contact with immigrant languages. As stated above, many words common in the city are also derived from these foreign languages.<ref>Labov 1972</ref>
Although some features of traditional New York City English are receding among younger speakers, Labov concludes that, in terms of any major recent developments, the New York accent appears to be basically stable.<ref name="Labov 2010">Labov, William (2010). ''[http://www.cogsci.msu.edu/DSS/2011-2012/Labov/POLC%20Chapters%201-3.pdf The Politics of Language Change: Dialect Divergence in America] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161006040909/http://www.cogsci.msu.edu/DSS/2011-2012/Labov/POLC%20Chapters%201-3.pdf |date=October 6, 2016 }}''. The University of Virginia Press. Pre-publication draft. p. 53.</ref>
===Influence on other dialects=== Philadelphians born in the twentieth century exhibit a short-''a'' split system that some linguists regard as a simplification of the similar New York City short-''a'' system.<ref>Ash, Sharon (2002). "[http://repository.upenn.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1741&context=pwpl The Distribution of a Phonemic Split in the Mid-Atlantic Region: Yet More on Short ''a''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304113721/http://repository.upenn.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1741&context=pwpl |date=March 4, 2016 }}." University of Pennsylvania Working Papers in Linguistics. University of Pennsylvania. p. 1 </ref> The Philadelphia dialect is now retreating from many of the traditional features it once shared in common with New York City.<ref>Labov, W. & Rosenfelder, I. & Fruehwald, J.(2013). ''One Hundred Years of Sound Change in Philadelphia: Linear Incrementation, Reversal, and Reanalysis''. ''Language'', 89(1), p. 61.</ref>
Due to an influx of immigrants from New York City and neighboring New Jersey to Florida, some residents of southern Florida now speak with an accent reminiscent of a New York accent. Additionally, as a result of social and commercial contact between the two cities and the influx of immigrants from the same countries,{{cn|date=August 2018}} the traditional dialect of [[New Orleans, Louisiana]], known locally as "[[Yat (New Orleans)|Yat]]", bears distinctive similarities with the New York dialect, including the (moribund) [[coil–curl merger]], raising of {{IPAc-en|ɔː}} to {{IPA|[ɔə]}}, a similar split in the short-''a'' system, and [[th-stopping|''th''-stopping]]. Therefore, older New York City English presumably influenced dialect evolution in the white working class of [[New Orleans]] (and possibly vice versa), as well as in [[Cincinnati, Ohio]], and [[Albany, New York]], whose older speakers today may still exhibit a short-''a'' split system that appears to be an expanded or generalized variant of the New York City short-''a'' system. Unsurprisingly, certain New York City dialect features also appear in [[New York Latino English]].
===Recent developments=== Though [[William Labov]] argues that the New York accent is generally stable at the moment,<ref name="Labov 2010"/> some recent studies have revealed a trend of recession in certain features of the accent, especially among younger speakers from middle-class or higher backgrounds. Documented loss of New York City accent features includes the loss of: the [[coil–curl merger]] (now almost completely extinct), non-rhoticity, and the extremely raised long vowel [ɔː] (as in ''talk'', ''cough'', or ''law''). Researchers proposed that the motivation behind these recessive trends is the stigmatization against the typical New York accent since the mid-1900s as being associated with a poorer or working-class background, often also corresponding with particular ethnic identities. While earlier projects detected trends of emphasizing New York accents as part of a process of social identification, recent researches attribute the loss of typical accent features to in-group ethnic distancing. In other words, many of the young generations of ethnic groups who formerly were the most representative speakers of the accent are currently avoiding its features in order to not stand out socially and/or ethnically.<ref>Becker, K. (2014). ''http://www.reed.edu/linguistics/becker/Becker_2014_BOUGHT.pdf'' {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161013022927/http://www.reed.edu/linguistics/becker/Becker_2014_BOUGHT.pdf |date=October 13, 2016 }}, Language in Society, Vol. 43, No. 4, (Apr. 2014), pp. 395–420.</ref>
==Pronunciation== {{main|New York accent}} The pronunciation of New York City English, most popularly acknowledged by the term "New York accent", is readily noticed and stereotyped, garnering considerable attention in American culture.<ref name="Labov et al., 2006, p. 233">Labov et al., 2006, p. 233</ref> Some well-known phonological features include its traditional [[rhoticity in English|dropping of ''r'']], a [[/æ/ tensing|short-''a'' split system]] (in which, for example, the ''a'' in ''gas'' is not [[Assonance|assonant]] to the ''a'' in ''gap''), a [[close vowel|high]] [[diphthong|gliding]] vowel in words like ''talk'', ''thought'', ''all'', etc. (and thus an absence of the [[cot-caught merger]]),<ref name="Labov et al., 2006, p. 233"/> absence of the [[Mary-marry-merry merger]], and the stigmatized (and largely now-extinct) [[coil–curl merger]].<ref>Labov et al., 2006, p. 260</ref>
==Vocabulary and grammar== {{See also| Regional vocabularies of American English}}
There are some words used mainly in Greater New York City. For instance, a "stoop" (from the [[Dutch language|Dutch]] word ''"stoep"'') is the front steps of a building. In the black and Latino communities, the word ''punk'' tends to be used as a synonym for ''weak'', ''someone unwilling or unable to defend himself'' or perhaps ''loser,'' though it appears to descend from an outdated [[African-American English]] meaning of ''male receptive participant in anal sex''.<ref>Arthur Spears, "African American language: Ideology and so-called obscenity"; in Salikoko Mufwene, John Rickford, Guy Bailey and John Baugh (eds.) ''African American English: Structure, History, and Use'' (London: Routledge), pp. 226–250</ref>
New Yorkers tend to say they stand ''on'' line, whereas most other American-English speakers tend to stand ''in'' line.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2012/11/semantics-voting-you-say-line-i-say-line/321708|title=The Semantics of Voting: You Say 'On Line,' I Say 'In Line'|first=Jen|last=Doll|date=|website=theatlantic.com|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170219093823/https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2012/11/semantics-voting-you-say-line-i-say-line/321708/|archivedate=February 19, 2017|df=mdy-all}}</ref> Small convenience stores are, in recent decades, often called ''bodegas,'' from the Spanish term originally meaning "a wine storehouse" via the [[Puerto Rican Spanish]] term for "small store; corner store", or ''delis,'' which is the short form of ''[[delicatessen]]s''.
==Conversational styles==
New York speakers have some unique conversational styles. Linguistic professor Deborah Tannen notes in a ''New York Times'' article it has "an emphasis to involve the other person, rather than being considerate. It would be asking questions as a show of interest in the other person, whereas in other parts of [the] country, people don't ask because it might put the person on the spot." New Yorkers "stand closer, talk louder, and leave shorter pauses between exchanges," Tannen said. "I call it 'cooperative overlap'. It's a way of showing interest and enthusiasm, but it's often mistaken for interrupting by people from elsewhere in the country." On the other hand, linguist William Labov demurs, "there's nothing known to linguists about 'normal New York City conversation'"<ref>John Leland, "Was it 'normal New York City conversation'?" ''New York Times'', June 9, 2017</ref>

==Geographic boundaries==
===New York State=== New York City English is confined to a geographically small but densely populated area, including all [[five boroughs]] of New York City, but not all of [[New York State]]; an entirely [[Inland Northern American English|separate dialect]] predominates in [[central New York|central]] and [[Western New York|western New York State]], especially along the [[Great Lakes region|Great Lakes]].<ref name="Labov et al. 2006"/> However, New York City English does extend beyond the city proper, including in western [[Long Island]] (although the boundaries there are not clearly established).<ref>Labov, William. 2010. Principles of Linguistic Change, V. 3: Cognitive and Cultural Factors. Cambridge/NY Cambridge University Press. Chapter 15, footnote 13. p.390 {{cite web |url=http://www.ling.upenn.edu/phonoatlas/PLC3/PLC3.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-06-18 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100614200507/http://www.ling.upenn.edu/phonoatlas/PLC3/PLC3.html |archivedate=June 14, 2010 |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref>Bakht, Maryam (2010) ''Lexical variation and the negotiation of linguistic style in a Long Island middle school'' unpublished doctoral dissertation NYU</ref><ref>Olivo, Ann Marie (2013) ''The Strong Island Sound: Sociolinguistic Evidence for Emerging American Ethnicities.'' unpublished doctoral dissertation, Rice University</ref> Moreover, the English of the [[Hudson Valley]] forms a continuum of speakers who gather more features of New York City English the closer they are in geographic relation to the city itself;<ref name="Labov et al. 2006">{{Harvcoltxt|Labov|Ash|Boberg|2006}}</ref> some of the dialect's features may be heard as far north as the city of [[Albany, New York|Albany]].<ref>{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1353/lan.2007.0082 | last1 = Labov | first1 = William | year = 2007 | title = Transmission and Diffusion | url = http://www.ling.upenn.edu/~wlabov/Papers/TD.html | journal = [[Language (journal)|Language]] | volume = 83 | issue = 2 | pages = 344–387 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090228102652/http://www.ling.upenn.edu/~wlabov/Papers/TD.html | archivedate = February 28, 2009 | df = mdy-all }}</ref>
===New Jersey=== The [[Gateway Region|northeast quarter]] of [[New Jersey]], prominently [[Bergen County, New Jersey|Bergen]], [[Hudson County, New Jersey|Hudson]], and [[Essex County, New Jersey|Essex]] counties, including the cities [[Weehawken, New Jersey|Weehawken]], [[Hoboken, New Jersey|Hoboken]], [[Jersey City, New Jersey|Jersey City]], [[Bayonne, New Jersey|Bayonne]], and [[Newark, New Jersey|Newark]],<ref>Labov, William (2007) "Transmission and Diffusion", Language June 2007 p. 17</ref> plus Middlesex and Monmouth Counties, are all within the [[New York City metropolitan area]] and thus also home to the major features of New York City English. With the exception of New York City's immediate neighbors like Jersey City and Newark,<ref name="Labov et al., 2006, p. 47"/> the New York metropolitan dialect as spoken in New Jersey is [[Rhotic and non-rhotic accents|rhotic]] (or fully ''r''-pronouncing), so that, whereas a Brooklynite might pronounce "over there" something like "ovah theah/deah" {{IPA|[oʊvə ˈd̪ɛə]}}, an [[Elizabeth, New Jersey|Elizabeth]] native might say "over there/dare" {{IPA|[oʊvɚ ˈd̪ɛɚ]}}. ''[[The Atlas of North American English]]'' by [[William Labov]] et al. shows that the New York City [[Phonological history of English short A|short-''a'']] pattern has diffused to many ''r''-pronouncing communities in northern New Jersey like [[Rutherford, New Jersey|Rutherford]] (Labov's birthplace) and [[North Plainfield, New Jersey|North Plainfield]]. However, in these communities, the [[function word]] constraint is lost and the [[Syllable#Structure|open syllable]] constraint is variable.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ling.upenn.edu/phonoatlas/PLC3/Ch15.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2017-02-24 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120304121104/http://www.ling.upenn.edu/phonoatlas/PLC3/Ch15.pdf |archivedate=March 4, 2012 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>

revision.text:
The '''Oriental Club of Philadelphia''' is one of the oldest continuously-active academic clubs in the United States. It was founded on April 30th, 1888, with the aim of "bring[ing] together those interested in the several fields of Oriental study, for the interchange of ideas, and the encouragement of Oriental research."<ref>''Oriental Studies: A selection of the papers read before the Oriental Club of Philadelphia, 1888-1894'' (Boston: Ginn and Co., 1894), p. 7.</ref> The club was founded by scholars and other prominent intellectuals in the [[Philadelphia]] area interested in sharing new research and archaeological findings about the cultures of South Asia, East Asia, and the Near East. Its membership was initially limited to thirty, and meetings consisted of monthly lectures, held in the houses of members.<ref>James David Thompson, ''Handbook of Learned Societies and Institutions: America'' (Washington, D.C.: Carnegie Institution of Washington, 1908), p. 333.</ref>
Members in the early days of the club included some of the founding figures in American scholarship on Sanskrit, the Ancient Near East, Judaica, and the art and archaeology of Asia. Among the club's founders were [[Cyrus Adler]], Tatsui Baba, [[George Boardman the Younger|George Dana Boardman]], [[Stewart Culin]], Morton W. Easton, [[Paul Haupt]], [[Edward Washburn Hopkins]], [[Marcus Jastrow]], [[Morris Jastrow, Jr.]], [[Benjamin Smith Lyman]], Robert W. Rogers, Mayer Sulzberger, [[Henry Clay Trumbull]], and Talcott Williams.<ref>R. G. Kent and I. G. Matthews, “The Oriental Club of Philadelphia,” ''Journal of the American Oriental Society'' 58.1 (1938), p. 2.</ref> Other early members included [[William F. Albright]], [[Robert Pierpont Blake]], [[Rhys Carpenter]], [[Franklin Edgerton]], W. Max Müller, [[E. A. Speiser]], and [[Solomon Zeitlin]].
The fifth anniversary of the Oriental Club of Philadelphia was marked by the publication of a volume of studies.<ref>''Oriental Studies: A selection of the papers read before the Oriental Club of Philadelphia, 1888-1894'' (Boston: Ginn and Co., 1894)</ref> For the twenty-fifth anniversary of the club's foundation in 1913, it entertained the [[American Oriental Society]]. The thirty-fifth anniversary of the foundation was marked by a colloquium in 1923, the proceedings of which were published in 1924;<ref>W.H. Schoff, ed., ''The Song of Songs, a Symposium by members of the Oriental Club of Philadelphia'' (Philadelphia: Commercial Museum, 1924)</ref> the volume features essays by Max L. Margolis, James A. Montgomery, Walter Woodburn Hyde, Franklin Edgerton, and Theophile J. Meek. For the fiftieth anniversary of the Oriental Club of Philadelphia in 1938, the club invited the [[American Oriental Society]] to meet in Philadelphia. In 1989, under the direction of William Hanaway, the Oriental Club of Philadelphia mounted a major conference with the participation of academic clubs from around the world. The recent history of the Oriental Club of Philadelphia was the topic for discussion at the Annual Banquet on April 25, 2001, preserved in audio on the CD “An Oral History of the Oriental Club."<ref>[http://www.theorientalclub.org/history/ http://www.theorientalclub.org/history/ - accessed 5/6/2008]</ref>
According to the club's website, the Oriental Club of Philadelphia "continues to be a forum for the academic exchange of ideas about the literature and languages of Asia, North Africa, and the Near and Middle East. The club brings together scholars in the Philadelphia area who work on the cultures of these regions from a variety of different perspectives, including History, Art History, Anthropology, Philosophy, and Religious Studies. Members include faculty and staff of universities and museums in the Philadelphia area. Sponsored events include presentations of works-in-progress by members, an annual lecture and banquet, and public colloquia on themes of cross-cultural concern."<ref>[http://www.theorientalclub.org/past-events/ http://www.theorientalclub.org/past-events/ - accessed 5/6/2008]</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==Sources== *S. Culin, ''Chinese games with dice; read before the Oriental club of Philadelphia, March 14, 1889'' (Philadelphia: Franklin, 1889) *D.G. Brinton and M. Jastrow, ''The cradle of the Semites: two papers read before the Philadelphia Oriental Club'' (Philadelphia, 1890). *''Oriental Studies: A selection of the papers read before the Oriental Club of Philadelphia, 1888-1894'' (Boston: Ginn and Co., 1894), pp. 3-16. *''The Oriental Club of Philadelphia: record of 25 years'' (Philadelphia, 1913). *R.G. Kent, ed., ''Thirty years of Oriental Studies, issued in commemoration of thirty years of activity of the Oriental Club of Philadelphia'' (Philadelphia, 1918). *R. G. Kent and I. G. Matthews, “The Oriental Club of Philadelphia,” ''Journal of the American Oriental Society'' 58.1 (1938), pp. 2-4. *[http://www.theorientalclub.org/ The Oriental Club of Philadelphia homepage]
